question_text: As Director (F&A), which control architecture for Internal Audit meaning and responsibility is most defensible under FR 1701?
option_a: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_b: Existence of IA Unit does not remove individual responsibilities or normal departmental checks
option_c: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_d: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
explanation: FR 1701 emphasises that Existence of IA Unit does not remove individual responsibilities or normal departmental checks.

question_text: Which director-level risk control best complies with FR 1702 on Placement of competent accountant for IA units?
option_a: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_b: Accountant-General ensures suitably competent Accountant placed directly in charge of Internal Audit Units
option_c: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_d: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
explanation: FR 1702 emphasises that Accountant-General ensures suitably competent Accountant placed directly in charge of Internal Audit Units.

question_text: Which directorate policy best aligns accountability with FR 1703 for Reporting lines and programme of audit?
option_a: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_b: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_c: Submits detailed programme initially; monthly progress reports
option_d: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
explanation: FR 1703 emphasises that Submits detailed programme initially; monthly progress reports.

question_text: Which director-level decision is most consistent with FR 1704 in managing Annual audit programme scope?
option_a: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_b: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_c: Programme covers safeguards against fraud/loss, revenue control, expenditure control, stores control, verification of cash/stores/assets, accuracy of records
option_d: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
explanation: FR 1704 emphasises that Programme covers safeguards against fraud/loss, revenue control, expenditure control, stores control, verification of cash/stores/assets, accuracy of records.

question_text: As Director (F&A), which control architecture for Pre-payment audit and 48-hour rule is most defensible under FR 1705?
option_a: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_b: Only sample-based (10%) pre-payment audit is required for checked vouchers.
option_c: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_d: Vouchers must not be held in IA Unit for more than 48 hours
explanation: FR 1705 emphasises that Vouchers must not be held in IA Unit for more than 48 hours.

question_text: Which director-level risk control best complies with FR 1706 on Periodic IA reports and content?
option_a: Issues special reports on irregularity/weakness and draws attention to Auditor-General or earlier IA reports; copies forwarded to AG and Auditor-General
option_b: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_c: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_d: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
explanation: FR 1706 emphasises that Issues special reports on irregularity/weakness and draws attention to Auditor-General or earlier IA reports; copies forwarded to AG and Auditor-General.

question_text: Which directorate policy best aligns accountability with FR 1707 for Register to track audit progress?
option_a: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_b: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_c: Head IA maintains under personal control a register to record progress of the audit
option_d: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
explanation: FR 1707 emphasises that Head IA maintains under personal control a register to record progress of the audit.

question_text: Which director-level decision is most consistent with FR 1708 in managing Internal audit instructions?
option_a: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_b: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_c: Head IA draws up detailed IA instructions for staff; comprehensive amplification of audit guide
option_d: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
explanation: FR 1708 emphasises that Head IA draws up detailed IA instructions for staff; comprehensive amplification of audit guide.

question_text: As Director (F&A), which control architecture for Independence of IA staff is most defensible under FR 1709?
option_a: IA staff shall not be employed on accounting duties within the ministry/unit
option_b: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_c: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_d: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
explanation: FR 1709 emphasises that IA staff shall not be employed on accounting duties within the ministry/unit.

question_text: Which director-level risk control best complies with FR 1710 on Internal audit stamps as security instruments?
option_a: IA certification is through Internal Audit stamps
option_b: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_c: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_d: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
explanation: FR 1710 emphasises that IA certification is through Internal Audit stamps.

question_text: Which directorate policy best aligns accountability with FR 1711 for Eligibility and application for audit stamps?
option_a: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_b: Particulars: name/rank, two passport photos stamped/endorsed, specimen signatures, evidence of posting
option_c: Passport photographs are optional if specimen signatures are provided.
option_d: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
explanation: FR 1711 emphasises that Particulars: name/rank, two passport photos stamped/endorsed, specimen signatures, evidence of posting.

question_text: Which director-level decision is most consistent with FR 1712 in managing Daily custody and register for audit stamps?
option_a: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_b: Audit stamps may be left with each user overnight if kept in a locked drawer.
option_c: Outstations follow same arrangement
option_d: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
explanation: FR 1712 emphasises that Outstations follow same arrangement.

question_text: As Director (F&A), which control architecture for Non-transferability and return of stamps is most defensible under FR 1713?
option_a: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_b: Audit stamps are not transferable
option_c: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_d: Returned stamps may be re-issued to another officer after endorsement by Head of Internal Audit.
explanation: FR 1713 emphasises that Audit stamps are not transferable.

question_text: Which director-level risk control best complies with FR 1714 on Sanctions for loss of audit stamp?
option_a: Loss of an audit stamp attracts only a written warning regardless of negligence.
option_b: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_c: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_d: Internal auditor who loses an audit stamp through negligence bears maximum penalty of surcharge or replacement cost as confirmed by Accountant-General
explanation: FR 1714 emphasises that Internal auditor who loses an audit stamp through negligence bears maximum penalty of surcharge or replacement cost as confirmed by Accountant-General.

question_text: Which directorate policy best aligns accountability with FR 1715 for Access rights of Internal Auditor?
option_a: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_b: Internal Auditor has free access at reasonable times to stores and store records for independent audit
option_c: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_d: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
explanation: FR 1715 emphasises that Internal Auditor has free access at reasonable times to stores and store records for independent audit.

question_text: Which director-level decision is most consistent with FR 1801 in managing Annual boards of survey (domestic)?
option_a: Boards of Survey are held only at the end of each quarter, not at year-end.
option_b: Examine cash, bank balances, and stamps held at sub-treasury, FPOs, cash offices in ministries etc
option_c: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
option_d: Annual Boards of Survey are convened by the Auditor-General rather than Treasury Inspectorate.
explanation: FR 1801 emphasises that Examine cash, bank balances, and stamps held at sub-treasury, FPOs, cash offices in ministries etc.

question_text: As Director (F&A), which control architecture for Annual boards of survey (missions overseas) is most defensible under FR 1802?
option_a: Treasury Inspectorate calls for mission survey returns in January, not August.
option_b: Boards of Survey are held only at the end of each quarter, not at year-end.
option_c: Annual boards for missions overseas on cash/bank/stamps held; Head of Mission convenes
option_d: A Board of Survey may be constituted with members below GL.08 if supervised.
explanation: FR 1802 emphasises that Annual boards for missions overseas on cash/bank/stamps held; Head of Mission convenes.

question_text: Which director-level risk control best complies with FR 1803 on Surprise boards of survey (domestic)?
option_a: Director and authorised officers may make surprise inspections; appointment kept confidential
option_b: A Board of Survey may be constituted with members below GL.08 if supervised.
option_c: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
option_d: The appointment of surprise Boards may be openly announced for transparency.
explanation: FR 1803 emphasises that Director and authorised officers may make surprise inspections; appointment kept confidential.

question_text: Which directorate policy best aligns accountability with FR 1804 for Surprise boards of survey (missions overseas)?
option_a: Boards of Survey are held only at the end of each quarter, not at year-end.
option_b: A Board of Survey may be constituted with members below GL.08 if supervised.
option_c: Reports of Boards of Survey may be submitted within six weeks after the survey.
option_d: Surprise boards at missions overseas three times each year; Head of Mission convenes; held at intervals as 1803
explanation: FR 1804 emphasises that Surprise boards at missions overseas three times each year; Head of Mission convenes; held at intervals as 1803.

question_text: Which director-level decision is most consistent with FR 1805 in managing Composition and conduct of board?
option_a: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
option_b: Board consists of three officers including President
option_c: Boards of Survey are held only at the end of each quarter, not at year-end.
option_d: Reports of Boards of Survey may be submitted within six weeks after the survey.
explanation: FR 1805 emphasises that Board consists of three officers including President.

question_text: As Director (F&A), which control architecture for Suspension of cash transactions during survey is most defensible under FR 1806?
option_a: A Board of Survey may be constituted with members below GL.08 if supervised.
option_b: Unverified cash may be kept in the cashierâs drawer if the safe is full.
option_c: No cash transactions between year-end close and time of survey
option_d: Reports of Boards of Survey may be submitted within six weeks after the survey.
explanation: FR 1806 emphasises that No cash transactions between year-end close and time of survey.

question_text: Which director-level risk control best complies with FR 1807 on Certification and treatment of surplus/shortage?
option_a: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
option_b: A Board of Survey may be constituted with members below GL.08 if supervised.
option_c: Certify cash balance on original and duplicate cash book
option_d: Reports of Boards of Survey may be submitted within six weeks after the survey.
explanation: FR 1807 emphasises that Certify cash balance on original and duplicate cash book.

question_text: Which directorate policy best aligns accountability with FR 1808 for Board report TF42 and timelines?
option_a: On completion of survey, report in triplicate on Revised TF42 signed by all members
option_b: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
option_c: Boards of Survey are held only at the end of each quarter, not at year-end.
option_d: Reports of Boards of Survey may be submitted within six weeks after the survey.
explanation: FR 1808 emphasises that On completion of survey, report in triplicate on Revised TF42 signed by all members.

question_text: Which director-level decision is most consistent with FR 1809 in managing Irregular inspections by Accounting Officers?
option_a: Only Internal Audit may inspect subordinate cash holdings; Accounting Officers need not issue instructions.
option_b: Accounting Officers issue instructions for systematic inspection at irregular intervals of cash held by subordinate officers; record kept
option_c: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
option_d: Inspection records are optional if no discrepancies are found.
explanation: FR 1809 emphasises that Accounting Officers issue instructions for systematic inspection at irregular intervals of cash held by subordinate officers; record kept.

option_d: An officer who negligently disregards cheque acceptance checks and receives a dishonoured cheque is surcharged for the full amount.
explanation: FR 731 provides that An officer who negligently disregards cheque acceptance checks and receives a dishonoured cheque is surcharged for the full amount.

question_text: During operations, which step best implements FR 732?
option_a: Bills of Exchange and Promissory Notes require specific AccountantâGeneral approval before acceptance.
option_b: Defaced cheques must be cancelled and retained, banks notified, and a cancelled cheque register maintained.
option_c: To ensure salary payment by the 28th monthly, quarterly remittance schedules and advance preparation are required; CBN provides credit/debit advice for reconciliation.
option_d: Dishonoured cheque debits must be cleared/refunded by next business day and must never be treated or held as cash.
explanation: FR 732 provides that Dishonoured cheque debits must be cleared/refunded by next business day and must never be treated or held as cash.

question_text: Which workflow control aligns with FR 733?
option_a: Dishonoured revenue cheques must be reversed to the original head, reimbursement pursued (including legal action if needed), bank nonâappearance investigated, and no Treasury receipt issued until clearance.
option_b: Cheques should be payable to the Federal Government (or official designation), crossed appropriately on receipt, and accepted only after strict validity checks (including confirmation above â¦20,000).
option_c: Requests for official cheque books must be signed by an authorised account signatory and countersigned by the Head of Accounts.
option_d: A departmental dishonoured cheque register must be kept and reviewed monthly by the Head of Accounts to ensure recoveries are pursued.
explanation: FR 733 provides that A departmental dishonoured cheque register must be kept and reviewed monthly by the Head of Accounts to ensure recoveries are pursued.

question_text: In day-to-day processing, which action supports FR 734?
option_a: Cheque books must be securely stored and controlled; officers operating accounts must prevent extraction of cheque leaves for fraud.
option_b: Foreign cheques/currencies require prescribed approvals and prompt remittance to CBN/SubâTreasurer for negotiation; missions must not accept unusable currencies.
option_c: Government funds must not be placed in banks charging commissions; monthly statements must confirm no commission on turnover is charged.
option_d: Postâdated cheques require prior AccountantâGeneral authority before acceptance.
explanation: FR 734 provides that Government funds must not be placed in banks charging commissions; monthly statements must confirm no commission on turnover is charged.

question_text: Which routine practice demonstrates compliance with FR 735?
option_a: Bills of Exchange and Promissory Notes require specific AccountantâGeneral approval before acceptance.
option_b: Idle funds of MDAs may only be invested in Treasury Bills in line with extant circulars.
option_c: Officers incurring unauthorised commission charges on cheques are liable to surcharge of the amount involved.
option_d: Postâdated cheques require prior AccountantâGeneral authority before acceptance.
explanation: FR 735 provides that Officers incurring unauthorised commission charges on cheques are liable to surcharge of the amount involved.

question_text: Your office is tightening controls. Which measure reflects FR 736?
option_a: Overhead remittances to field offices must follow AIE/cash transfer procedures, complete within 7 working days, with sanctions/interest for delays and monthly reconciliation reporting.
option_b: Personal cheques must not be exchanged for cash from government funds under any circumstances.
option_c: Cheques should be payable to the Federal Government (or official designation), crossed appropriately on receipt, and accepted only after strict validity checks (including confirmation above â¦20,000).
option_d: Cheque books must be securely stored and controlled; officers operating accounts must prevent extraction of cheque leaves for fraud.
explanation: FR 736 provides that Cheque books must be securely stored and controlled; officers operating accounts must prevent extraction of cheque leaves for fraud.

question_text: Which operational safeguard best applies FR 737?
option_a: Dishonoured cheque debits must be cleared/refunded by next business day and must never be treated or held as cash.
option_b: Cheque books must be securely stored and controlled; officers operating accounts must prevent extraction of cheque leaves for fraud.
option_c: Cheques should be payable to the Federal Government (or official designation), crossed appropriately on receipt, and accepted only after strict validity checks (including confirmation above â¦20,000).
option_d: Defaced cheques must be cancelled and retained, banks notified, and a cancelled cheque register maintained.
explanation: FR 737 provides that Defaced cheques must be cancelled and retained, banks notified, and a cancelled cheque register maintained.

question_text: A unit is revising procedures. Which action complies with FR 738?
option_a: Bank tellers/paying-in-slips must specify cheques/notes/coins, bear bank acknowledgment without alteration, and show the correct stamped account number.
option_b: Cheques received must be banked by next business day; special remittance steps apply for commission cheques and cheques must not be endorsed to third parties.
option_c: Idle funds of MDAs may only be invested in Treasury Bills in line with extant circulars.
option_d: Defaced cheques must be cancelled and retained, banks notified, and a cancelled cheque register maintained.
explanation: FR 738 provides that Bank tellers/paying-in-slips must specify cheques/notes/coins, bear bank acknowledgment without alteration, and show the correct stamped account number.

question_text: Which administrative decision matches FR 739?
option_a: Idle funds of MDAs may only be invested in Treasury Bills in line with extant circulars.
option_b: Overhead remittances to field offices must follow AIE/cash transfer procedures, complete within 7 working days, with sanctions/interest for delays and monthly reconciliation reporting.
option_c: Postâdated cheques require prior AccountantâGeneral authority before acceptance.
option_d: To ensure salary payment by the 28th monthly, quarterly remittance schedules and advance preparation are required; CBN provides credit/debit advice for reconciliation.
explanation: FR 739 provides that Idle funds of MDAs may only be invested in Treasury Bills in line with extant circulars.

question_text: In administrative practice, how should FR 1001 guide actions related to definition and purpose of imprest?
option_a: It delegates the matter entirely to private discretion.
option_b: It establishes the official rule governing definition and purpose of imprest.
option_c: It suspends normal procedures concerning definition and purpose of imprest.
option_d: It removes all accountability related to definition and purpose of imprest.
explanation: FR 1001 specifically defines the official regulatory framework for definition and purpose of imprest.

option_a: It suspends normal procedures concerning limits and frequency of standing imprests.

question_text: Scenario: A cashier has â¦2,000,000 in cash after close of business, far above the next dayâs needs. What is the correct next step under FR 1101?
option_a: Hold excess cash in the office strong-room for a week first
option_b: Pay excess cash into the bank immediately (beyond daily needs)
option_c: Keep excess cash in the cashierâs safe until month end
option_d: Use excess cash to settle pending claims before deposit
explanation: FR 1101 requires maximum use of banking facilities and immediate banking of cash beyond daily requirements. (FR 1101)

question_text: Scenario: A compliance issue is identified during routine operations. What is the correct next step under FR 1102?
option_a: Keep all reserve stocks in the cashierâs drawer since it is convenient
option_b: Keep surplus cash/stamps/receipt books in a strong-room or reserve safe with at least two locks held by different officers
option_c: Use a single-lock safe and let the cashier keep the only key
option_d: Store reserve books on open shelves provided the room is locked
explanation: FR 1102 mandates strong-room/reserve safe custody with dual-lock control (cashier + senior officer). (FR 1102)

question_text: You are supervising a cash point. Which action best implements FR 1103?
option_a: Store daily working cash in the strong-room only during office hours
option_b: Use a portable safe that can be moved home after work
option_c: Keep the daily cash balance on a desk in the cashierâs office
option_d: Provide a securely fixed (built-in/attached) safe for the daily working cash balance and stamp/receipt book stocks during office hours
explanation: FR 1103 is about a secure safe for daily working balances during office hours, physically secured to the structure. (FR 1103)

question_text: You are supervising a cash point. Which action best implements FR 1104?
option_a: Allow the officer to transport cash privately in a personal car
option_b: Send cash by commercial courier without escort
option_c: Carry cash in a sealed envelope as long as it is signed over
option_d: Use an approved cash tank/box plus a government vehicle and police escort for cash transport
explanation: FR 1104 sets minimum safeguards for transporting cash: approved container, official vehicle, and police escort. (FR 1104)

question_text: In managing day-to-day operations, which decision satisfies FR 1105?
option_a: Focus only on cleaning the strong-room floor monthly
option_b: Check only the locks; vents/openings are not relevant
option_c: Inspect strong-rooms periodically for vents/openings and store currency notes in lidded boxes (not loose)
option_d: Store notes loose on shelves for faster counting
explanation: FR 1105 requires periodic physical security checks and proper storage of notes in boxes with lids. (FR 1105)

question_text: In managing day-to-day operations, which decision satisfies FR 1106?
option_a: Provide custody facilities only if theft has already occurred
option_b: Let each department buy any safe model without guidance
option_c: Procure safes first and request specifications after delivery
option_d: Ensure officers handling public money/stamps have proper custody facilities; obtain specifications from the Accountant-General before procuring safes/strong-rooms/cash tanks
explanation: FR 1106 places responsibility on Accounting Officers and requires AG specifications before procurement of custody equipment. (FR 1106)

question_text: Scenario: A compliance issue is identified during routine operations. What is the correct next step under FR 1107?
option_a: Allow cashiers to keep both original and duplicate keys
option_b: Send duplicate keys home with the most trusted clerk
option_c: Issue key-security instructions; keep all duplicate keys with the Accounting Officer and maintain a key register (with possible FPO custody outside Abuja by arrangement)
option_d: Keep duplicate keys unrecorded to avoid bureaucracy
explanation: FR 1107 governs key security: AO controls duplicates, register maintained; FPO custody may apply outside Abuja; MFA issues overseas rules. (FR 1107)

question_text: In managing day-to-day operations, which decision satisfies FR 1108?
option_a: Permit one officer to hold both keys to reduce delays
option_b: Keep both keys on a hook in the strong-room
option_c: Do not allow one officer to hold keys to both the strong-room and the safe inside it
option_d: Give both keys to the cashier during peak periods
explanation: FR 1108 enforces segregation of key custody when a safe is inside a strong-room. (FR 1108)

question_text: You are supervising a cash point. Which action best implements FR 1109?
option_a: Make a private duplicate key without notifying anyone
option_b: Continue using the safe and âhopeâ the duplicate turns up
option_c: Original key holders must confirm duplicate keys exist; if missing/untraceable, report and request lock alteration/new keys
option_d: Ignore missing duplicates unless a theft occurs
explanation: FR 1109 requires verification of duplicate key availability and formal action if duplicates are missing. (FR 1109)

question_text: Operationally, FR 1110 requires which of the following?
option_a: Leave keys in a shared drawer for convenience
option_b: Keep keys on the safe door hook after closing
option_c: Key holders must keep keys in personal possession and are responsible for the contents; keys must not leave their possession unless officially handed over
option_d: Lend keys to junior staff when busy
explanation: FR 1110 establishes personal custody of keys and collective responsibility for contents. (FR 1110)

question_text: Operationally, FR 1111 requires which of the following?
option_a: Wait until the next audit before reporting the loss
option_b: Report key loss immediately; seal the safe, place a police guard if valuables exist, use duplicate key only to open for verification/removal, then change locks before reuse
option_c: Replace the key by copying another key without changing locks
option_d: Open the safe quietly with a duplicate key and continue using it
explanation: FR 1111 sets the emergency procedure for lost keys: immediate reporting, sealing, guarding, controlled opening, and lock replacement. (FR 1111)

question_text: Operationally, FR 1112 requires which of the following?
option_a: A negligent officer who loses a government safe key may be required to pay the cost of changing the lock and new keys
option_b: The ministry must always bear the cost regardless of negligence
option_c: Only the police can decide who pays for lock changes
option_d: Key losses have no financial consequences
explanation: FR 1112 ties key-loss negligence to financial liability for lock alteration and new keys. (FR 1112)

question_text: Operationally, FR 1113 requires which of the following?
option_a: Continue using the safe but increase counting frequency
option_b: Ask a technician to âtightenâ the lock without reporting
option_c: Wait to see if anything goes missing before acting
option_d: If interference is suspected, move contents to another safe, report as in FR 1111, and request immediate lock alteration/new keys; notify other key holders
explanation: FR 1113 is a âsuspected compromiseâ protocol: relocate contents, report, change locks, notify key holders. (FR 1113)

question_text: Scenario: A compliance issue is identified during routine operations. What is the correct next step under FR 1114?
option_a: A contractor may do it without supervision
option_b: Lock alterations and new keys must be done by the Accounting Officer under security conditions
option_c: Locks can be changed informally to save time
option_d: Any clerk may change locks as long as receipts are kept
explanation: FR 1114 centralizes and secures lock-change processes under the Accounting Officer. (FR 1114)

question_text: You are supervising a cash point. Which action best implements FR 1115?
option_a: Render annual returns (in duplicate) of all government strong-rooms and safes on 31 March to the Accountant-General for record checks/updates
option_b: Submit returns only when new safes are purchased
option_c: Submit returns on 31 December to the Budget Office
option_d: Submit returns quarterly to the Auditor-General only
explanation: FR 1115 requires annual returns of safes/strong-rooms to the Accountant-General on 31 March. (FR 1115)

question_text: Operationally, FR 1116 requires which of the following?
option_a: Notify only after the annual returns are prepared
option_b: Transfer safes without notification as long as inventory is updated internally
option_c: Notify the Accountant-General immediately of safe transfers between stations/departments and inform duplicate key holders to forward keys securely if needed
option_d: Hand keys to the transport officer with the safe
explanation: FR 1116 ensures AG records and duplicate-key custody stay accurate when safes move. (FR 1116)

question_text: Scenario: A compliance issue is identified during routine operations. What is the correct next step under FR 1117?
option_a: Retain old keys in the cashierâs desk
option_b: When locks change or a safe is condemned/destroyed, inform duplicate key holders so old keys are destroyed and removed from records
option_c: Keep old keys âjust in caseâ the safe is repaired
option_d: Send old keys to the bank for disposal
explanation: FR 1117 prevents obsolete keys from remaining in circulation and requires record write-off. (FR 1117)

question_text: You are supervising a cash point. Which action best implements FR 1118?
option_a: Only authorised key holders may open strong-rooms/safes and they must remain present while open (all key holders present if multiple)
option_b: Open the safe and leave it open while officers attend meetings
option_c: Allow any senior staff to open the safe if a key holder is absent
option_d: Permit opening as long as CCTV is installed
explanation: FR 1118 restricts access to authorised key holders and requires their presence during opening. (FR 1118)

question_text: In managing day-to-day operations, which decision satisfies FR 1119?
option_a: Allow private money if it is sealed in an envelope
option_b: Do not keep private money/personal effects in official safes; any private money found must be credited to revenue
option_c: Record private money as âmiscellaneous depositsâ automatically
option_d: Return private money to the owner without accounting for it
explanation: FR 1119 prohibits private items in official safes and treats private money found as revenue. (FR 1119)

question_text: You are supervising a cash point. Which action best implements FR 1120?
option_a: Ensure cashierâs cash balance is locked in a strong-room/reserve safe at close daily; where provided, do not keep cash overnight in the cashierâs safe
option_b: Leave cash in drawers if the office has security guards
option_c: Keep overnight cash in the cashierâs safe for faster morning access
option_d: Bank the cash weekly instead of daily locking
explanation: FR 1120 sets end-of-day custody: strong-room/reserve safe, not cashierâs safe when a strong-room exists. (FR 1120)

question_text: Operationally, FR 1121 requires which of the following?
option_a: Keep strong-room/safe registers for cash, stamps, receipt/licence books, etc., showing denominations separately; entries signed by key holders; issue receipts for documents/articles deposited
option_b: Record totals only; denominations are optional
option_c: Maintain registers only for cash, not stamps or books
option_d: Allow entries to be unsigned as long as they are typed
explanation: FR 1121 prescribes detailed registers and signature controls for items kept in strong-rooms/safes. (FR 1121)

question_text: In managing day-to-day operations, which decision satisfies FR 1122?
option_a: Sign the register only if discrepancies are found
option_b: Check contents only during annual stock-taking
option_c: Sub-Accounting Officers must check strong-room/safe contents at least monthly against the register and sign the register on each occasion; report discrepancies
option_d: Delegate checks to the cashier without review
explanation: FR 1122 requires monthly reconciliation of physical contents to the register, with signatures and reporting of discrepancies. (FR 1122)

question_text: You are supervising a cash point. Which action best implements FR 1123?
option_a: Store bonds in open filing cabinets for easy access
option_b: Send agreements home with the contract officer
option_c: Keep bonds/agreements in secure custody; Accounting Officers are responsible if government suffers financially due to poor safeguards
option_d: Keep bonds only in electronic form without backup
explanation: FR 1123 stresses safe custody of key legal documents and holds AOs accountable for losses due to inadequate precautions. (FR 1123)

question_text: In managing day-to-day operations, which decision satisfies FR 1124?
option_a: Leave the key in the key holderâs drawer until return
option_b: Hand all keys to one officer to simplify access
option_c: Give the key to any available staff member without record
option_d: When a key holder is temporarily absent, hand the key to the next officer in rank against signature in the key register; never allow all keys to be held by one officer
explanation: FR 1124 regulates temporary key handover and forbids concentration of all keys with one officer. (FR 1124)

question_text: You are supervising a cash point. Which action best implements FR 1125?
option_a: Handover keys without checking contents to avoid delays
option_b: File certificates separately; no need to record in the register
option_c: Check contents only if the cash balance seems unusual
option_d: On any handover of keys, check the contents and insert certificates in the register; report discrepancies to the Accounting Officer
explanation: FR 1125 requires joint verification and documentation whenever key custody changes. (FR 1125)

question_text: Operationally, FR 1126 requires which of the following?
option_a: Release deposited documents/articles only on depositorâs demand and production of the deposit receipt; obtain acknowledgement on the receipt and paste it in the register
option_b: Release documents on a verbal request from the depositor
option_c: Release documents if the depositor shows an ID card only
option_d: Return documents and keep the receipt with the depositor
explanation: FR 1126 ties release to the deposit receipt and requires acknowledgement and record-keeping. (FR 1126)

question_text: Scenario: A compliance issue is identified during routine operations. What is the correct next step under FR 1127?
option_a: Keep postage stocks under the sole custody of the cashier
option_b: Hold postage stocks with the procurement officer only
option_c: Main stocks of postal valuables (stamps, postal orders, etc.) must be held in joint custody of officers appointed by the Accounting Officer and the Minister of Communications
option_d: Let each unit keep its own postage stocks independently
explanation: FR 1127 sets joint-custody arrangements for major postage-related stocks. (FR 1127)

question_text: Scenario: Registered letters with valuables arrive from the Post Office for delivery to the office. What is the correct next step under FR 1128?
option_a: Allow the postman to open the bag and hand over items
option_b: Receive valuable letters in open trays for quicker sorting
option_c: Provide a padlocked Post-Office mail bag for valuable mail; key kept by the officer in charge and opened in his presence
option_d: Let the cashier keep the padlock key and open the bag alone
explanation: FR 1128 secures valuable mail delivery using a padlocked bag and controlled opening. (FR 1128)

question_text: You are supervising a cash point. Which action best implements FR 1129?
option_a: Record only outward letters; inward letters are optional
option_b: Do not file Post Office receipts once letters are sent
option_c: Allow unsigned entries if the register is kept electronically
option_d: Maintain a register for inward/outward registered letters (and unregistered valuables), signed by officer-in-charge; file and number Post Office receipts for outward letters and reference them in the register
explanation: FR 1129 requires documented tracking of registered letters and valuables, with signed entries and controlled receipt filing. (FR 1129)

question_text: Scenario: A compliance issue is identified during routine operations. What is the correct next step under FR 1130?
option_a: Store security documents in open shelves if the room is guarded
option_b: Lock security documents/forms (e.g., receipt/licence books, cheque books, LPO books, contracts, bonds, insurance policies, securities) overnight in a safe/strong-room/security cabinet and safeguard them during the day
option_c: Lock only contracts; other books can remain in drawers
option_d: Keep cheque books on the cashierâs desk for convenience
explanation: FR 1130 lists key security documents and requires robust safe custody arrangements. (FR 1130)

question_text: Operationally, FR 1131 requires which of the following?
option_a: Protect core accounting records (cash books, ledgers, journals, registers, asset records, used receipt books, etc.) from unauthorised access and fireâpreferably in a strong-room or safe overnight
option_b: Allow anyone to access ledgers as long as they sign a visitor book
option_c: Lock only the cash book; other records can remain on tables
option_d: Store records near windows for ventilation even overnight
explanation: FR 1131 mandates precautions (access + fire) for specified accounting records; strong-room/safe is preferred protection. (FR 1131)

question_text: Scenario: A records officer is planning disposal of old accounting books and vouchers. What is the correct next step under FR 1132?
option_a: Destroy payment vouchers immediately after monthly accounts are submitted
option_b: Destroy procurement records after one year to free space
option_c: Retain specified security books/records for prescribed periods (permanent/10 years/7 years/2 years) and only destroy certain items after Auditor-General audit
option_d: Keep all documents permanently with no disposal
explanation: FR 1132 sets retention schedules and allows destruction of some records only after the Auditor-Generalâs audit. (FR 1132)

question_text: In managing records under FR 1201 (responsibility for control), which step is correct? (Choose the most appropriate action.)
option_a: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_b: The Accountant-General controls Treasury Receipt Books (T.B.6) and Revenue Collectorsâ Receipt Books (T.B.6A), while Accounting Officers control Receipt/Licence Books and Fixed Fee Tickets and ensure safe custody.
option_c: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_d: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
explanation: FR 1201 requires: The Accountant-General controls Treasury Receipt Books (T.B.6) and Revenue Collectorsâ Receipt Books (T.B.6A), while Accounting Officers control Receipt/Licence Books and Fixed Fee Tickets and ensure safe custody.

question_text: For effective administration under FR 1202 (printing/numbering requirements), which procedure is appropriate? (Choose the most appropriate action.)
option_a: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_b: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_c: Receipt and licence books must follow the prescribed form and each leaflet must have serial, consecutive numbers; all copies in a set carry the same printed serial/consecutive numbers.
option_d: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).

question_text: In managing records under FR 1207 (control/procedure requirement), which step is correct? (Choose the most appropriate action.)

question_text: For effective administration under FR 1208 (serial-order issuance), which procedure is appropriate? (Choose the most appropriate action.)

question_text: A unit is implementing controls for FR 1209 (prohibitions/restrictions). What should be done first? (Choose the most appropriate action.)

question_text: In managing records under FR 1210 (control/procedure requirement), which step is correct? (Choose the most appropriate action.)

question_text: For effective administration under FR 1211 (issue note (RBIN) procedures), which procedure is appropriate? (Choose the most appropriate action.)
option_a: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).

explanation: FR 1211 requires: On receipt, issues must be checked against the RBIN; books examined for numbering/printing defects; discrepancies reported to supplying officer with copies to AG and Auditor-General; receiver is responsible after receipting and returning the duplicate RBIN.

question_text: A unit is implementing controls for FR 1212 (control/procedure requirement). What should be done first? (Choose the most appropriate action.)

question_text: For effective administration under FR 1214 (prohibitions/restrictions), which procedure is appropriate? (Choose the most appropriate action.)

question_text: For effective administration under FR 1220 (control/procedure requirement), which procedure is appropriate? (Choose the most appropriate action.)

question_text: A unit is implementing controls for FR 1221 (control/procedure requirement). What should be done first? (Choose the most appropriate action.)
option_a: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.

question_text: In managing records under FR 1222 (control/procedure requirement), which step is correct? (Choose the most appropriate action.)

question_text: A unit is implementing controls for FR 1224 (control/procedure requirement). What should be done first? (Choose the most appropriate action.)

question_text: A unit is implementing controls for FR 1305 (control/procedure requirement). What should be done first? (Choose the most appropriate action.)

question_text: In managing records under FR 1306 (deposit withdrawal documentation), which step is correct? (Choose the most appropriate action.)

question_text: For effective administration under FR 1307 (control/procedure requirement), which procedure is appropriate? (Choose the most appropriate action.)

question_text: A unit is implementing controls for FR 1308 (control/procedure requirement). What should be done first? (Choose the most appropriate action.)

explanation: FR 1308 requires: At financial year end, the Director of Finance and Accounts compiles a certified list of unwithdrawn deposits (certified by Internal Audit) and forwards it to the Accountant-General for refund at the start of the new year.

question_text: In managing records under FR 1309 (control/procedure requirement), which step is correct? (Choose the most appropriate action.)

option_b: Deposits over two years old (except prisonersâ property) must not be repaid without prior approval of the Accounting Officer.

question_text: For effective administration under FR 1310 (control/procedure requirement), which procedure is appropriate? (Choose the most appropriate action.)
option_a: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).

question_text: A unit is implementing controls for FR 1311 (control/procedure requirement). What should be done first? (Choose the most appropriate action.)

option_b: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.

explanation: FR 1311 requires: Refunds of Immigration Restriction Act deposits require authority of the Accounting Officer of the Ministry of Interior; authority must be attached to voucher and referenced.

question_text: In managing records under FR 1312 (reconciliation requirement), which step is correct? (Choose the most appropriate action.)

question_text: For effective administration under FR 1313 (control/procedure requirement), which procedure is appropriate? (Choose the most appropriate action.)

explanation: FR 1313 requires: Deposit ledgers must be balanced and ruled off at financial year end, carrying down outstanding balances with adequate cross-references.

question_text: For administrative planning under FR 1401, which workflow is correct?
option_a: Any advance to an officer, whether personal or official, authorised solely by the Accountant-General.
option_b: An imprest issued for routine office expenditure, repayable only at year-end.
option_c: A deposit held below-the-line for third parties and refundable on demand.
option_d: Ensure that: A cash loan to an individual federal officer, grantable only under the Financial Regulations and Public Service Rules.
explanation: FR 1401 limits personal advances to cash loans to individual officers and restricts them to the authority of the Financial Regulations and Public Service Rules.

question_text: As a unit head, you must operationalise FR 1402. Which practice best aligns with the regulation?
option_a: A cash loan to an officer for private needs, approved by any Head of Department without limits.
option_b: Any advance above ?50,000 that can be approved by the Accounting Officer without exception.
option_c: A revenue refund mechanism that must always be approved by the Auditor-General.
option_d: Ensure that: An official-capacity advance (e.g., imprest/loss-of-funds), generally requiring Minister of Finance approval except FR 2524 cases or up to ?50,000 approved by the Accounting Officer, with applications stating reason, clearance method, and responsible person.
explanation: FR 1402 defines non-personal advances and sets approval rules (Minister of Finance, with stated exceptions), plus application content and project governance.

question_text: For administrative planning under FR 1403, which workflow is correct?
option_a: Only the vote book sub-head and the paying station code.
option_b: Ensure that: Officers name/designation, below-the-line classification code, nature of advance, recovery terms, and authority for the advance.
option_c: Only the cheque number and bank account designation.
option_d: Only the suppliers invoice reference and LPO number.
explanation: FR 1403 specifies the mandatory particulars that must appear on vouchers relating to advances.

question_text: As a unit head, you must operationalise FR 1404. Which practice best aligns with the regulation?
option_a: Record advances only at year-end and reconcile only during external audit.
option_b: Keep advance records unindexed and reconcile only when a query is raised.
option_c: Delegate advance ledger control entirely to the cashier without review.
option_d: Maintain fully indexed advance account records, post transactions promptly, reconcile monthly with the Accountant-Generals control, and flag overdue items to the Accounting Officer.
explanation: FR 1404 sets record-keeping, timeliness, reconciliation, and monitoring requirements for advance accounts.

question_text: As a unit head, you must operationalise FR 1405. Which practice best aligns with the regulation?
option_a: Ensure advances are converted to deposits when repayment delays occur.
option_b: Ensure advances are charged to revenue heads until recovered.
option_c: Ensure advances are repaid promptly, whether by instalments or otherwise.
option_d: Ensure advances are written off automatically after one year.
explanation: FR 1405 assigns Accounting Officers responsibility for prompt repayment of all advances.

question_text: You are designing procedures for compliance with FR 1406. Which control/step is most appropriate?
option_a: Grant advance only after the officer returns and submits vouchers.
option_b: Ensure that: Grant up to one months salary advance to an officer on transfer who bears transport costs wholly or partly.
option_c: Grant up to three months salary advance automatically to any transferring officer.
option_d: Grant an imprest instead of a salary advance for family transport costs.
explanation: FR 1406 allows a salary advance on transfer, capped at one months salary, tied to transport costs borne by the officer.

question_text: You are designing procedures for compliance with FR 1407. Which control/step is most appropriate?
option_a: Approve payment only through deposits, not salary advances.
option_b: Approve an estacode advance up to three months salary for any overseas posting.
option_c: Ensure that: Approve a salary advance up to one months salary for an officer posted to an overseas office/duty.
option_d: Approve an advance only if the officer is GL.15 and above.
explanation: FR 1407 provides for a salary advance of up to one months salary for overseas posting.

question_text: For administrative planning under FR 1408, which workflow is correct?
option_a: Ensure that: On first appointment, grant up to one months salary; for temporary appointment, grant up to one months salary only with an acceptable guarantee.
option_b: Grant temporary appointees salary advances without any guarantee requirement.
option_c: Grant two months salary to all first appointees as entitlement.
option_d: Grant advances only after confirmation of appointment.
explanation: FR 1408 sets limits for first appointment and adds a guarantee condition for temporary appointments.

question_text: As a unit head, you must operationalise FR 1409. Which practice best aligns with the regulation?
option_a: Repay all salary advances in a single lump sum within 30 days, regardless of amount.
option_b: Repay 3-month advance over 12 instalments and start deductions immediately in the same month.
option_c: Repay 1-month advance over 6 instalments and allow deductions up to 75% of salary.
option_d: Ensure that: Repay 1-month advance in 3 equal consecutive instalments starting next month; 2- and 3-month advances in up to 6 and 9 instalments; total deductions must not exceed half monthly salary.
explanation: FR 1409 fixes instalment lengths by advance size and caps total deductions at not more than half of monthly salary.

question_text: You are designing procedures for compliance with FR 1410. Which control/step is most appropriate?
option_a: Ensure that: Classify salary advances and recoveries to the below-the-line advance account in the officers name, not to personal emoluments.
option_b: Classify advances to capital sub-heads and recoveries to suspense accounts.
option_c: Classify recoveries to revenue heads and advances to overhead cost vote.
option_d: Classify salary advances to personal emoluments vote to simplify reconciliation.
explanation: FR 1410 is a classification rule: below-the-line advance account in the officers name; never personal emoluments vote.

question_text: As a unit head, you must operationalise FR 1411. Which practice best aligns with the regulation?
option_a: Per diem excludes feeding and is payable only after audit clearance; transport is per-mile at a fixed dollar rate.
option_b: Ensure that: Local DTA per diem rates by cadre (?35,000; ?20,000; ?16,000; ?12,000; ?5,000) with ?20/km transport where no air, plus 30% local running; only for approved tours; charge direct to vote without retirement.
option_c: Uniform ?10,000 per diem for all grades, with retirement required within 48 hours.
option_d: Per diem rates are set by each ministry quarterly and must be retired to deposit accounts.
explanation: FR 1411 sets specific per diem and transport rules for duty tours within Nigeria, plus charging and approval conditions.

question_text: For administrative planning under FR 1412, which workflow is correct?
option_a: Ensure that: Accounting Officer authorises estacode at prevailing rates: $900, $600, $425, $381, $206 per diem by cadre.
option_b: Estacode is authorised by the Auditor-General and paid as a fixed monthly allowance.
option_c: Estacode is paid only after return from travel and must be retired like an imprest.
option_d: Estacode rates are uniform at $300 per diem regardless of grade.
explanation: FR 1412 specifies that the Accounting Officer authorises estacode and provides the grade-based per diem rates.

question_text: For administrative planning under FR 1413, which workflow is correct?
option_a: Pay estacode in cash abroad from mission revenue accounts without approvals.
option_b: Issue estacode as bank drafts payable to the mission and later reallocate by journal entry.
option_c: Pay additional estacode automatically if the officer overstays, without refund obligation.
option_d: Ensure that: Draw estacode in Nigeria as travellers cheques payable to the officer(s) from CBN; extra estacode by mission requires Accounting Officer approval and must be refunded by the ministry/agency.
explanation: FR 1413 prescribes the instrument (travellers cheques), source (CBN), and approval/refund rules for additional estacode.

question_text: In implementing FR 1414 across stations, which approach is correct?
option_a: Overstay is allowed if the officer sends an email to the paying officer after the fact.
option_b: Overstay is allowed for GL.15 and above without further approvals.
option_c: Ensure that: Do not overstay the approved number of days on duty tour without prior Accounting Officer approval.
option_d: Overstay is allowed if the officer uses personal funds for extra days.
explanation: FR 1414 is a strict approval rule: no overstaying locally or overseas without prior Accounting Officer approval.

question_text: In implementing FR 1415 across stations, which approach is correct?
option_a: Ensure that: Authorise only if conditions are met: work-related, efficiency benefit, reputable institution, receipts produced, TF51 repayment agreement (+ surety if <2 years service), interest-free, excludes postage/stationery/exam fees, recover within 24 instalments.
option_b: Approve without agreement forms provided the officer promises to repay verbally.
option_c: Charge interest on the advance and recover over any period the officer requests.
option_d: Allow advances for any course, including unrelated hobbies, and include exam/other fees.
explanation: FR 1415 lists strict eligibility, documentation (TF51/surety), cost exclusions, and recovery limits for study-related advances.

question_text: For administrative planning under FR 1416, which workflow is correct?
option_a: Ensure that: Recover the outstanding balance in full from the officers last salary and/or retirement gratuity on exit.
option_b: Write off the balance when an officer resigns if more than half has been recovered.
option_c: Suspend recovery until the next financial year to avoid excess expenditure.
option_d: Transfer the balance to revenue once the officer leaves.
explanation: FR 1416 mandates full recovery of any outstanding advance balance from final salary and/or gratuity upon leaving service.

question_text: For administrative planning under FR 1417, which workflow is correct?
option_a: Recover from next of kins salary if employed in government.
option_b: Recover from the estate in all cases, regardless of gratuity entitlement.
option_c: Ensure that: Do not recover the outstanding salary advance balance from the estate where the deceased officer is not entitled to gratuity; government bears the irrecoverable balance.
option_d: Convert the balance to a deposit and hold for five years before transfer to revenue.
explanation: FR 1417 creates a specific exception: if no gratuity entitlement, the estate is not charged; government accepts liability.

question_text: You are designing procedures for compliance with FR 1418. Which control/step is most appropriate?
option_a: Send only a verbal handover note; the Personal Emolument Record is not required.
option_b: Close the advance ledger at the old station and restart recovery from zero at the new station.
option_c: State advance details and recoveries in the Last Pay Certificate sent to the new station with certified true Personal Emolument Record; new station SAO records the balance and continues recovery.
option_d: Convert the outstanding balance to an imprest at the new station.
explanation: FR 1418 establishes the documentation and continuity steps for recovering advances after transfer to a new pay station.

question_text: For administrative planning under FR 1419, which workflow is correct?
option_a: The absence of advice does not excuse non-repayment; missed instalments are deducted en bloc once the appropriate documents arrive.
option_b: If advice is missing, instalments are waived automatically.
option_c: If advice is missing, recoveries must wait until the officer requests deduction.
option_d: If advice is missing, convert the instalments to interest-bearing debt.
explanation: FR 1419 makes repayment obligatory regardless of advice and permits en bloc deduction of missed instalments once documentation is received.

question_text: As a unit head, you must operationalise FR 1420. Which practice best aligns with the regulation?
option_a: Ensure advances are classified to overhead votes to simplify budgeting.
option_b: Ensure that all advances granted are fully recovered.
option_c: Ensure advances are retired only at the end of the officers career.
option_d: Ensure advances are issued promptly even if recovery systems are not in place.
explanation: FR 1420 states the Accounting Officers overarching duty: complete recovery of all advances.

question_text: Which control procedure satisfies FR 1501?
option_a: It is enforced only after complaints
option_b: Compliance must follow the specific provision stated in FR 1501
option_c: It is required only for temporary staff
option_d: It applies only when funds permit
explanation: FR 1501 explicitly requires adherence to its stated rule.

question_text: Why is a unit designated selfâaccounting?
option_a: To eliminate audits
option_b: To decentralise detailed accounting responsibility
option_c: To avoid reporting
option_d: To reduce staffing
explanation: Status transfers detailed accounting responsibility to the Accounting Officer.

question_text: Before approval, what must exist structurally?
option_a: Press office
option_b: Accounting code approved by AG
option_c: Union office
option_d: Budget speech
explanation: Accounting code must be approved.

question_text: Purpose of placing accounts under Treasury Accountant is to:
option_a: Increase revenue
option_b: Ensure professional control
option_c: Reduce audits
option_d: Avoid reports
explanation: It ensures competent oversight.

question_text: Why compare voucher totals with variation sheets?
option_a: To reduce printing
option_b: To verify accuracy
option_c: To train staff
option_d: To file records
explanation: It ensures correctness.

question_text: Abstract records track what?
option_a: Attendance
option_b: Cumulative totals
option_c: Leave
option_d: Vehicles
explanation: They track totals.

question_text: Receipts vouchers kept relate to:
option_a: Personal letters
option_b: Accounting Officer transactions
option_c: Staff birthdays
option_d: Meetings
explanation: They relate to official transactions.

question_text: Why must schedule totals agree with accounts?
option_a: Decoration
option_b: Accuracy
option_c: Speed
option_d: Training
explanation: Agreement ensures accuracy.

question_text: Why link schedules to totals?
option_a: Decoration
option_b: Verification
option_c: Storage
option_d: Training
explanation: It verifies entries.

question_text: Cash backing must accompany:
option_a: Leave form
option_b: Departmental Warrant
option_c: ID card
option_d: Report
explanation: It must accompany warrant.

question_text: Primary basis for withdrawal is:
option_a: Politics
option_b: Regulation breach
option_c: Weather
option_d: Age
explanation: Failure to comply.

question_text: You are designing procedures for Internal Audit meaning and responsibility. Which workflow best satisfies FR 1701?
option_a: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_b: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_c: Internal Audit is a managerial control that measures/evaluates effectiveness of Internal Control system
option_d: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
explanation: FR 1701 emphasises that Internal Audit is a managerial control that measures/evaluates effectiveness of Internal Control system.

question_text: During monthly planning for Placement of competent accountant for IA units, which control arrangement implements FR 1702 correctly?
option_a: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_b: Accountant-General ensures suitably competent Accountant placed directly in charge of Internal Audit Units
option_c: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_d: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
explanation: FR 1702 emphasises that Accountant-General ensures suitably competent Accountant placed directly in charge of Internal Audit Units.

question_text: To reduce exceptions in Reporting lines and programme of audit, which administrative process matches FR 1703?
option_a: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_b: Submits detailed programme initially; monthly progress reports
option_c: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_d: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
explanation: FR 1703 emphasises that Submits detailed programme initially; monthly progress reports.

question_text: As part of internal controls for Annual audit programme scope, which operational plan complies with FR 1704?
option_a: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_b: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_c: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_d: Programme covers safeguards against fraud/loss, revenue control, expenditure control, stores control, verification of cash/stores/assets, accuracy of records
explanation: FR 1704 emphasises that Programme covers safeguards against fraud/loss, revenue control, expenditure control, stores control, verification of cash/stores/assets, accuracy of records.

question_text: You are designing procedures for Pre-payment audit and 48-hour rule. Which workflow best satisfies FR 1705?
option_a: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_b: Vouchers must not be held in IA Unit for more than 48 hours
option_c: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_d: Only sample-based (10%) pre-payment audit is required for checked vouchers.
explanation: FR 1705 emphasises that Vouchers must not be held in IA Unit for more than 48 hours.

question_text: During monthly planning for Periodic IA reports and content, which control arrangement implements FR 1706 correctly?
option_a: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_b: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_c: IA produces monthly, quarterly and half-yearly reports to Accounting Officer with copies to AG and Auditor-General
option_d: Special reports are sent only to the Accounting Officer without copies to oversight offices.
explanation: FR 1706 emphasises that IA produces monthly, quarterly and half-yearly reports to Accounting Officer with copies to AG and Auditor-General.

question_text: To reduce exceptions in Register to track audit progress, which administrative process matches FR 1707?
option_a: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_b: Head IA maintains under personal control a register to record progress of the audit
option_c: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_d: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
explanation: FR 1707 emphasises that Head IA maintains under personal control a register to record progress of the audit.

question_text: As part of internal controls for Internal audit instructions, which operational plan complies with FR 1708?
option_a: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_b: Explain nature of accounts relative to ministry function; references to law and relevant accounting instructions
option_c: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_d: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
explanation: FR 1708 emphasises that Explain nature of accounts relative to ministry function; references to law and relevant accounting instructions.

question_text: You are designing procedures for Independence of IA staff. Which workflow best satisfies FR 1709?
option_a: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_b: IA staff shall not be employed on accounting duties within the ministry/unit
option_c: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_d: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
explanation: FR 1709 emphasises that IA staff shall not be employed on accounting duties within the ministry/unit.

question_text: During monthly planning for Internal audit stamps as security instruments, which control arrangement implements FR 1710 correctly?
option_a: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_b: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_c: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_d: IA certification is through Internal Audit stamps
explanation: FR 1710 emphasises that IA certification is through Internal Audit stamps.

question_text: To reduce exceptions in Eligibility and application for audit stamps, which administrative process matches FR 1711?
option_a: Head IA submits names/particulars of staff empowered to use stamps; ranks not below GL09 in Abuja and GL08 outside Abuja
option_b: Audit stamp users may be as low as GL.06 if supervised by Head of Internal Audit.
option_c: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_d: Passport photographs are optional if specimen signatures are provided.
explanation: FR 1711 emphasises that Head IA submits names/particulars of staff empowered to use stamps; ranks not below GL09 in Abuja and GL08 outside Abuja.

question_text: As part of internal controls for Daily custody and register for audit stamps, which operational plan complies with FR 1712?
option_a: Released next day; daily issue/return recorded in Daily Release of Audit Stamps Register
option_b: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_c: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_d: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
explanation: FR 1712 emphasises that Released next day; daily issue/return recorded in Daily Release of Audit Stamps Register.

question_text: You are designing procedures for Non-transferability and return of stamps. Which workflow best satisfies FR 1713?
option_a: Returned stamps may be re-issued to another officer after endorsement by Head of Internal Audit.
option_b: Re-assigned auditors return stamps to Head IA; Head IA forwards to AG and informs Accounting Officer; stamps must not be re-issued
option_c: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_d: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
explanation: FR 1713 emphasises that Re-assigned auditors return stamps to Head IA; Head IA forwards to AG and informs Accounting Officer; stamps must not be re-issued.

question_text: During monthly planning for Sanctions for loss of audit stamp, which control arrangement implements FR 1714 correctly?
option_a: Internal auditor who loses an audit stamp through negligence bears maximum penalty of surcharge or replacement cost as confirmed by Accountant-General
option_b: Loss of an audit stamp attracts only a written warning regardless of negligence.
option_c: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_d: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
explanation: FR 1714 emphasises that Internal auditor who loses an audit stamp through negligence bears maximum penalty of surcharge or replacement cost as confirmed by Accountant-General.

question_text: To reduce exceptions in Access rights of Internal Auditor, which administrative process matches FR 1715?
option_a: Internal Auditor has free access at reasonable times to stores and store records for independent audit
option_b: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_c: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_d: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
explanation: FR 1715 emphasises that Internal Auditor has free access at reasonable times to stores and store records for independent audit.

question_text: As part of internal controls for Annual boards of survey (domestic), which operational plan complies with FR 1801?
option_a: Director, Treasury Inspectorate Dept (OAGF) convenes annual boards; calls for cash offices list by first week Aug; Accounting Officers send info by first week Oct; Director appoints members and advises AOs
option_b: Accounting Officers submit particulars of cash offices to be surveyed in December.
option_c: Cash transactions may continue during a survey provided they are recorded in the cash book.
option_d: Reports of Boards of Survey may be submitted within six weeks after the survey.
explanation: FR 1801 emphasises that Director, Treasury Inspectorate Dept (OAGF) convenes annual boards; calls for cash offices list by first week Aug; Accounting Officers send info by first week Oct; Director appoints members and advises AOs.

question_text: You are designing procedures for Annual boards of survey (missions overseas). Which workflow best satisfies FR 1802?
option_a: Annual surveys for missions overseas are convened by the Accountant-General, not Heads of Mission.
option_b: Director Treasury Inspectorate by first week Aug writes to MFA to ensure compliance
option_c: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
option_d: Boards of Survey are held only at the end of each quarter, not at year-end.
explanation: FR 1802 emphasises that Director Treasury Inspectorate by first week Aug writes to MFA to ensure compliance.

question_text: During monthly planning for Surprise boards of survey (domestic), which control arrangement implements FR 1803 correctly?
option_a: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
option_b: Reports of Boards of Survey may be submitted within six weeks after the survey.
option_c: Once in each of first three quarters; not necessarily end of month/quarter
option_d: The appointment of surprise Boards may be openly announced for transparency.
explanation: FR 1803 emphasises that Once in each of first three quarters; not necessarily end of month/quarter.

question_text: To reduce exceptions in Surprise boards of survey (missions overseas), which administrative process matches FR 1804?
option_a: Surprise boards at missions overseas three times each year; Head of Mission convenes; held at intervals as 1803
option_b: Reports of Boards of Survey may be submitted within six weeks after the survey.
option_c: Cash transactions may continue during a survey provided they are recorded in the cash book.
option_d: Boards of Survey are held only at the end of each quarter, not at year-end.
explanation: FR 1804 emphasises that Surprise boards at missions overseas three times each year; Head of Mission convenes; held at intervals as 1803.

question_text: As part of internal controls for Composition and conduct of board, which operational plan complies with FR 1805?
option_a: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
option_b: Cash transactions may continue during a survey provided they are recorded in the cash book.
option_c: Reports of Boards of Survey may be submitted within six weeks after the survey.
option_d: President GL10+; other members not below GL08; cash office officer present
