option_b: Provide a securely fixed (built-in/attached) safe for the daily working cash balance and stamp/receipt book stocks during office hours.
option_c: Keep the daily cash balance on a desk in the cashierâs office.
option_d: Use a portable safe that can be moved home after work.
explanation: FR 1103 is about a secure safe for daily working balances during office hours, physically secured to the structure. (FR 1103)

question_text: FR 1104 would be complied with by which action?
option_a: Use an approved cash tank/box plus a government vehicle and police escort for cash transport.
option_b: Allow the officer to transport cash privately in a personal car.
option_c: Carry cash in a sealed envelope as long as it is signed over.
option_d: Send cash by commercial courier without escort.
explanation: FR 1104 sets minimum safeguards for transporting cash: approved container, official vehicle, and police escort. (FR 1104)

question_text: Select the statement that correctly reflects FR 1105.
option_a: Store notes loose on shelves for faster counting.
option_b: Inspect strong-rooms periodically for vents/openings and store currency notes in lidded boxes (not loose).
option_c: Check only the locks; vents/openings are not relevant.
option_d: Focus only on cleaning the strong-room floor monthly.
explanation: FR 1105 requires periodic physical security checks and proper storage of notes in boxes with lids. (FR 1105)

question_text: FR 1106 would be complied with by which action?
option_a: Procure safes first and request specifications after delivery.
option_b: Provide custody facilities only if theft has already occurred.
option_c: Ensure officers handling public money/stamps have proper custody facilities; obtain specifications from the Accountant-General before procuring safes/strong-rooms/cash tanks.
option_d: Let each department buy any safe model without guidance.
explanation: FR 1106 places responsibility on Accounting Officers and requires AG specifications before procurement of custody equipment. (FR 1106)

question_text: FR 1107 would be complied with by which action?
option_a: Keep duplicate keys unrecorded to avoid bureaucracy.
option_b: Issue key-security instructions; keep all duplicate keys with the Accounting Officer and maintain a key register (with possible FPO custody outside Abuja by arrangement).
option_c: Allow cashiers to keep both original and duplicate keys.
option_d: Send duplicate keys home with the most trusted clerk.
explanation: FR 1107 governs key security: AO controls duplicates, register maintained; FPO custody may apply outside Abuja; MFA issues overseas rules. (FR 1107)

question_text: Which practice aligns with FR 1108?
option_a: Permit one officer to hold both keys to reduce delays.
option_b: Do not allow one officer to hold keys to both the strong-room and the safe inside it.
option_c: Give both keys to the cashier during peak periods.
option_d: Keep both keys on a hook in the strong-room.
explanation: FR 1108 enforces segregation of key custody when a safe is inside a strong-room. (FR 1108)

question_text: FR 1109 would be complied with by which action?
option_a: Ignore missing duplicates unless a theft occurs.
option_b: Make a private duplicate key without notifying anyone.
option_c: Original key holders must confirm duplicate keys exist; if missing/untraceable, report and request lock alteration/new keys.
option_d: Continue using the safe and âhopeâ the duplicate turns up.
explanation: FR 1109 requires verification of duplicate key availability and formal action if duplicates are missing. (FR 1109)

question_text: FR 1110 would be complied with by which action?
option_a: Keep keys on the safe door hook after closing.
option_b: Key holders must keep keys in personal possession and are responsible for the contents; keys must not leave their possession unless officially handed over.
option_c: Leave keys in a shared drawer for convenience.
option_d: Lend keys to junior staff when busy.
explanation: FR 1110 establishes personal custody of keys and collective responsibility for contents. (FR 1110)

question_text: Which practice aligns with FR 1111?
option_a: Wait until the next audit before reporting the loss.
option_b: Report key loss immediately; seal the safe, place a police guard if valuables exist, use duplicate key only to open for verification/removal, then change locks before reuse.
option_c: Open the safe quietly with a duplicate key and continue using it.
option_d: Replace the key by copying another key without changing locks.
explanation: FR 1111 sets the emergency procedure for lost keys: immediate reporting, sealing, guarding, controlled opening, and lock replacement. (FR 1111)

question_text: FR 1112 would be complied with by which action?
option_a: Only the police can decide who pays for lock changes.
option_b: The ministry must always bear the cost regardless of negligence.
option_c: Key losses have no financial consequences.
option_d: A negligent officer who loses a government safe key may be required to pay the cost of changing the lock and new keys.
explanation: FR 1112 ties key-loss negligence to financial liability for lock alteration and new keys. (FR 1112)

question_text: FR 1113 would be complied with by which action?
option_a: If interference is suspected, move contents to another safe, report as in FR 1111, and request immediate lock alteration/new keys; notify other key holders.
option_b: Ask a technician to âtightenâ the lock without reporting.
option_c: Continue using the safe but increase counting frequency.
option_d: Wait to see if anything goes missing before acting.
explanation: FR 1113 is a âsuspected compromiseâ protocol: relocate contents, report, change locks, notify key holders. (FR 1113)

question_text: Which practice aligns with FR 1114?
option_a: Lock alterations and new keys must be done by the Accounting Officer under security conditions.
option_b: Locks can be changed informally to save time.
option_c: Any clerk may change locks as long as receipts are kept.
option_d: A contractor may do it without supervision.
explanation: FR 1114 centralizes and secures lock-change processes under the Accounting Officer. (FR 1114)

question_text: Select the statement that correctly reflects FR 1115.
option_a: Submit returns quarterly to the Auditor-General only.
option_b: Submit returns only when new safes are purchased.
option_c: Render annual returns (in duplicate) of all government strong-rooms and safes on 31 March to the Accountant-General for record checks/updates.
option_d: Submit returns on 31 December to the Budget Office.
explanation: FR 1115 requires annual returns of safes/strong-rooms to the Accountant-General on 31 March. (FR 1115)

question_text: Which practice aligns with FR 1116?
option_a: Transfer safes without notification as long as inventory is updated internally.
option_b: Hand keys to the transport officer with the safe.
option_c: Notify only after the annual returns are prepared.
option_d: Notify the Accountant-General immediately of safe transfers between stations/departments and inform duplicate key holders to forward keys securely if needed.
explanation: FR 1116 ensures AG records and duplicate-key custody stay accurate when safes move. (FR 1116)

question_text: Select the statement that correctly reflects FR 1117.
option_a: Keep old keys âjust in caseâ the safe is repaired.
option_b: When locks change or a safe is condemned/destroyed, inform duplicate key holders so old keys are destroyed and removed from records.
option_c: Send old keys to the bank for disposal.
option_d: Retain old keys in the cashierâs desk.
explanation: FR 1117 prevents obsolete keys from remaining in circulation and requires record write-off. (FR 1117)

question_text: Select the statement that correctly reflects FR 1118.
option_a: Open the safe and leave it open while officers attend meetings.
option_b: Only authorised key holders may open strong-rooms/safes and they must remain present while open (all key holders present if multiple).
option_c: Permit opening as long as CCTV is installed.
option_d: Allow any senior staff to open the safe if a key holder is absent.
explanation: FR 1118 restricts access to authorised key holders and requires their presence during opening. (FR 1118)

question_text: FR 1119 would be complied with by which action?
option_a: Do not keep private money/personal effects in official safes; any private money found must be credited to revenue.
option_b: Return private money to the owner without accounting for it.
option_c: Record private money as âmiscellaneous depositsâ automatically.
option_d: Allow private money if it is sealed in an envelope.
explanation: FR 1119 prohibits private items in official safes and treats private money found as revenue. (FR 1119)

question_text: Which practice aligns with FR 1120?
option_a: Keep overnight cash in the cashierâs safe for faster morning access.
option_b: Leave cash in drawers if the office has security guards.
option_c: Ensure cashierâs cash balance is locked in a strong-room/reserve safe at close daily; where provided, do not keep cash overnight in the cashierâs safe.
option_d: Bank the cash weekly instead of daily locking.
explanation: FR 1120 sets end-of-day custody: strong-room/reserve safe, not cashierâs safe when a strong-room exists. (FR 1120)

question_text: Which practice aligns with FR 1121?
option_a: Record totals only; denominations are optional.
option_b: Keep strong-room/safe registers for cash, stamps, receipt/licence books, etc., showing denominations separately; entries signed by key holders; issue receipts for documents/articles deposited.
option_c: Allow entries to be unsigned as long as they are typed.
option_d: Maintain registers only for cash, not stamps or books.
explanation: FR 1121 prescribes detailed registers and signature controls for items kept in strong-rooms/safes. (FR 1121)

question_text: Select the statement that correctly reflects FR 1122.
option_a: Sign the register only if discrepancies are found.
option_b: Delegate checks to the cashier without review.
option_c: Sub-Accounting Officers must check strong-room/safe contents at least monthly against the register and sign the register on each occasion; report discrepancies.
option_d: Check contents only during annual stock-taking.
explanation: FR 1122 requires monthly reconciliation of physical contents to the register, with signatures and reporting of discrepancies. (FR 1122)

question_text: FR 1123 would be complied with by which action?
option_a: Keep bonds only in electronic form without backup.
option_b: Send agreements home with the contract officer.
option_c: Store bonds in open filing cabinets for easy access.
option_d: Keep bonds/agreements in secure custody; Accounting Officers are responsible if government suffers financially due to poor safeguards.
explanation: FR 1123 stresses safe custody of key legal documents and holds AOs accountable for losses due to inadequate precautions. (FR 1123)

question_text: FR 1124 would be complied with by which action?
option_a: Give the key to any available staff member without record.
option_b: Leave the key in the key holderâs drawer until return.
option_c: When a key holder is temporarily absent, hand the key to the next officer in rank against signature in the key register; never allow all keys to be held by one officer.
option_d: Hand all keys to one officer to simplify access.
explanation: FR 1124 regulates temporary key handover and forbids concentration of all keys with one officer. (FR 1124)

question_text: Which practice aligns with FR 1125?
option_a: On any handover of keys, check the contents and insert certificates in the register; report discrepancies to the Accounting Officer.
option_b: Check contents only if the cash balance seems unusual.
option_c: Handover keys without checking contents to avoid delays.
option_d: File certificates separately; no need to record in the register.
explanation: FR 1125 requires joint verification and documentation whenever key custody changes. (FR 1125)

question_text: Which practice aligns with FR 1126?
option_a: Return documents and keep the receipt with the depositor.
option_b: Release documents on a verbal request from the depositor.
option_c: Release documents if the depositor shows an ID card only.
option_d: Release deposited documents/articles only on depositorâs demand and production of the deposit receipt; obtain acknowledgement on the receipt and paste it in the register.
explanation: FR 1126 ties release to the deposit receipt and requires acknowledgement and record-keeping. (FR 1126)

question_text: Select the statement that correctly reflects FR 1127.
option_a: Keep postage stocks under the sole custody of the cashier.
option_b: Hold postage stocks with the procurement officer only.
option_c: Main stocks of postal valuables (stamps, postal orders, etc.) must be held in joint custody of officers appointed by the Accounting Officer and the Minister of Communications.
option_d: Let each unit keep its own postage stocks independently.
explanation: FR 1127 sets joint-custody arrangements for major postage-related stocks. (FR 1127)

question_text: Which option best matches the rule in FR 1128?
option_a: Provide a padlocked Post-Office mail bag for valuable mail; key kept by the officer in charge and opened in his presence.
option_b: Allow the postman to open the bag and hand over items.
option_c: Receive valuable letters in open trays for quicker sorting.
option_d: Let the cashier keep the padlock key and open the bag alone.
explanation: FR 1128 secures valuable mail delivery using a padlocked bag and controlled opening. (FR 1128)

question_text: FR 1129 would be complied with by which action?
option_a: Maintain a register for inward/outward registered letters (and unregistered valuables), signed by officer-in-charge; file and number Post Office receipts for outward letters and reference them in the register.
option_b: Do not file Post Office receipts once letters are sent.
option_c: Record only outward letters; inward letters are optional.
option_d: Allow unsigned entries if the register is kept electronically.
explanation: FR 1129 requires documented tracking of registered letters and valuables, with signed entries and controlled receipt filing. (FR 1129)

question_text: FR 1130 would be complied with by which action?
option_a: Lock only contracts; other books can remain in drawers.
option_b: Keep cheque books on the cashierâs desk for convenience.
option_c: Store security documents in open shelves if the room is guarded.
option_d: Lock security documents/forms (e.g., receipt/licence books, cheque books, LPO books, contracts, bonds, insurance policies, securities) overnight in a safe/strong-room/security cabinet and safeguard them during the day.
explanation: FR 1130 lists key security documents and requires robust safe custody arrangements. (FR 1130)

question_text: Which practice aligns with FR 1131?
option_a: Lock only the cash book; other records can remain on tables.
option_b: Store records near windows for ventilation even overnight.
option_c: Protect core accounting records (cash books, ledgers, journals, registers, asset records, used receipt books, etc.) from unauthorised access and fireâpreferably in a strong-room or safe overnight.
option_d: Allow anyone to access ledgers as long as they sign a visitor book.
explanation: FR 1131 mandates precautions (access + fire) for specified accounting records; strong-room/safe is preferred protection. (FR 1131)

question_text: Select the statement that correctly reflects FR 1132.
option_a: Keep all documents permanently with no disposal.
option_b: Retain specified security books/records for prescribed periods (permanent/10 years/7 years/2 years) and only destroy certain items after Auditor-General audit.
option_c: Destroy procurement records after one year to free space.
option_d: Destroy payment vouchers immediately after monthly accounts are submitted.
explanation: FR 1132 sets retention schedules and allows destruction of some records only after the Auditor-Generalâs audit. (FR 1132)

question_text: Which option correctly applies FR 1201 in practice?
option_a: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_b: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_c: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_d: The Accountant-General controls Treasury Receipt Books (T.B.6) and Revenue Collectorsâ Receipt Books (T.B.6A), while Accounting Officers control Receipt/Licence Books and Fixed Fee Tickets and ensure safe custody.
explanation: FR 1201 requires: The Accountant-General controls Treasury Receipt Books (T.B.6) and Revenue Collectorsâ Receipt Books (T.B.6A), while Accounting Officers control Receipt/Licence Books and Fixed Fee Tickets and ensure safe custody.

question_text: FR 1202 sets a rule that an officer must follow. Which is it?
option_a: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_b: Receipt and licence books must follow the prescribed form and each leaflet must have serial, consecutive numbers; all copies in a set carry the same printed serial/consecutive numbers.
option_c: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_d: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
explanation: FR 1202 requires: Receipt and licence books must follow the prescribed form and each leaflet must have serial, consecutive numbers; all copies in a set carry the same printed serial/consecutive numbers.

question_text: Under FR 1203, which action is required to comply?
option_a: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_b: Only the Accountant-General may place indents with NSPMC for T.B.6 and T.B.6A; revenue-earning receipt/licence books or fixed-fee ticket booklets must not be obtained from printers other than NSPMC or an AG-authorised printer.
option_c: The action is optional and may be done at the officerâs discretion.
option_d: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
explanation: FR 1203 requires: Only the Accountant-General may place indents with NSPMC for T.B.6 and T.B.6A; revenue-earning receipt/licence books or fixed-fee ticket booklets must not be obtained from printers other than NSPMC or an AG-authorised printer.

question_text: Which option correctly applies FR 1204 in practice?
option_a: All books received must be taken on charge in a stock and distribution register (TF 157), recorded in serial order and entered individually.
option_b: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_c: The action is optional and may be done at the officerâs discretion.
option_d: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
explanation: FR 1204 requires: All books received must be taken on charge in a stock and distribution register (TF 157), recorded in serial order and entered individually.

question_text: FR 1205 sets a rule that an officer must follow. Which is it?
option_a: Requests for Treasury Receipt Books go to the Accountant-General; Accounting Officers include revenue collectorsâ needs; issues are recorded and accompanied by an RBIN.
option_b: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_c: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_d: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
explanation: FR 1205 requires: Requests for Treasury Receipt Books go to the Accountant-General; Accounting Officers include revenue collectorsâ needs; issues are recorded and accompanied by an RBIN.

question_text: Under FR 1206, which action is required to comply?
option_a: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_b: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_c: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_d: Each issue must have a serially numbered RBIN printed in quadruplicate: original+duplicate to receiver (duplicate returned receipted), triplicate to Auditor-General, quadruplicate retained at office of issue.
explanation: FR 1206 requires: Each issue must have a serially numbered RBIN printed in quadruplicate: original+duplicate to receiver (duplicate returned receipted), triplicate to Auditor-General, quadruplicate retained at office of issue.

question_text: Which option correctly applies FR 1207 in practice?
option_a: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_b: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_c: Federal Pay Officers issue Treasury Receipt Book 6A to Revenue Collectors in their states using FR 1206 procedure and highlight serial numbers with the Security Book Issued Note.
option_d: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
explanation: FR 1207 requires: Federal Pay Officers issue Treasury Receipt Book 6A to Revenue Collectors in their states using FR 1206 procedure and highlight serial numbers with the Security Book Issued Note.

question_text: FR 1208 sets a rule that an officer must follow. Which is it?
option_a: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_b: Receipts may be issued in any order provided totals are correct at month-end.
option_c: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_d: Receipt and licence books must be issued for use in strict serial order.
explanation: FR 1208 requires: Receipt and licence books must be issued for use in strict serial order.

question_text: Under FR 1209, which action is required to comply?
option_a: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_b: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_c: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_d: Federal Revenue Collectors in a State must not request, stock, or issue State receipts to account for Federal Government revenue.
explanation: FR 1209 requires: Federal Revenue Collectors in a State must not request, stock, or issue State receipts to account for Federal Government revenue.

question_text: Which option correctly applies FR 1210 in practice?
option_a: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_b: Issues of receipt/licence forms to Revenue Collectors must not exceed daily needs; individual collectors must not hold stock.
option_c: The action is optional and may be done at the officerâs discretion.
option_d: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
explanation: FR 1210 requires: Issues of receipt/licence forms to Revenue Collectors must not exceed daily needs; individual collectors must not hold stock.

question_text: FR 1211 sets a rule that an officer must follow. Which is it?
option_a: The action is optional and may be done at the officerâs discretion.
option_b: On receipt, issues must be checked against the RBIN; books examined for numbering/printing defects; discrepancies reported to supplying officer with copies to AG and Auditor-General; receiver is responsible after receipting and returning the duplicate RBIN.
option_c: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_d: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
explanation: FR 1211 requires: On receipt, issues must be checked against the RBIN; books examined for numbering/printing defects; discrepancies reported to supplying officer with copies to AG and Auditor-General; receiver is responsible after receipting and returning the duplicate RBIN.

question_text: Under FR 1212, which action is required to comply?
option_a: Treasury receipt books issued for use must be recorded in the Receipt Book Register and safeguarded in a safe/strong-room; daily-use holders are responsible during the day and must secure them at close; temporary handover does not remove responsibility and must be checked on return.
option_b: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_c: The action is optional and may be done at the officerâs discretion.
option_d: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
explanation: FR 1212 requires: Treasury receipt books issued for use must be recorded in the Receipt Book Register and safeguarded in a safe/strong-room; daily-use holders are responsible during the day and must secure them at close; temporary handover does not remove responsibility and must be checked on return.

question_text: Which option correctly applies FR 1213 in practice?
option_a: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_b: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_c: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_d: Receipt and licence books must not be transferred between Sub-Accounting Officers without Accounting Officer consent, except emergencies which must be reported and follow FR 1205 procedure.
explanation: FR 1213 requires: Receipt and licence books must not be transferred between Sub-Accounting Officers without Accounting Officer consent, except emergencies which must be reported and follow FR 1205 procedure.

question_text: FR 1214 sets a rule that an officer must follow. Which is it?
option_a: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_b: The action is optional and may be done at the officerâs discretion.
option_c: Except when officially relieving, receipt/licence books (used or unused) must not be transferred between Revenue Collectors without Accountant-General approval.
option_d: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
explanation: FR 1214 requires: Except when officially relieving, receipt/licence books (used or unused) must not be transferred between Revenue Collectors without Accountant-General approval.

question_text: Under FR 1215, which action is required to comply?
option_a: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_b: Receipts may be issued in any order provided totals are correct at month-end.
option_c: Revenue receipts must be issued to payers in strict serial order and must not be altered.
option_d: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
explanation: FR 1215 requires: Revenue receipts must be issued to payers in strict serial order and must not be altered.

question_text: Which option correctly applies FR 1216 in practice?
option_a: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_b: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_c: The action is optional and may be done at the officerâs discretion.
option_d: A defaced or mutilated receipt/licence leaflet must be cancelled, marked 'cancelled' on all copies, and retained in the booklet for audit.
explanation: FR 1216 requires: A defaced or mutilated receipt/licence leaflet must be cancelled, marked 'cancelled' on all copies, and retained in the booklet for audit.

question_text: FR 1217 sets a rule that an officer must follow. Which is it?
option_a: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_b: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_c: The action is optional and may be done at the officerâs discretion.
option_d: The original receipt/licence leaflet must be handed over or delivered to the payer.
explanation: FR 1217 requires: The original receipt/licence leaflet must be handed over or delivered to the payer.

question_text: Under FR 1218, which action is required to comply?
option_a: Duplicates of receipts/licences (excluding fixed-fee counterfoil types) issued by Sub-Accounting Officers must be sent with the monthly account to the Accountant-General or Accounting Officer.
option_b: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_c: The action is optional and may be done at the officerâs discretion.
option_d: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
explanation: FR 1218 requires: Duplicates of receipts/licences (excluding fixed-fee counterfoil types) issued by Sub-Accounting Officers must be sent with the monthly account to the Accountant-General or Accounting Officer.

question_text: Which option correctly applies FR 1219 in practice?
option_a: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_b: Unused/obsolete receipts may be destroyed by a single officer without documentation.
option_c: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_d: Book copies of used receipt/licence books printed in triplicate may be destroyed two years after audit inspection unless retention is requested by relevant authorities.
explanation: FR 1219 requires: Book copies of used receipt/licence books printed in triplicate may be destroyed two years after audit inspection unless retention is requested by relevant authorities.

question_text: FR 1220 sets a rule that an officer must follow. Which is it?
option_a: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_b: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_c: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_d: For fixed-value receipt/licence leaflets, the receipt voucher bringing revenue to account must reference opening and closing serial numbers issued.
explanation: FR 1220 requires: For fixed-value receipt/licence leaflets, the receipt voucher bringing revenue to account must reference opening and closing serial numbers issued.

question_text: Under FR 1221, which action is required to comply?
option_a: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_b: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_c: Monthly certified returns of receipt/licence stock and use must show serial numbers at start, received, issued, and unused at end; revenue collectors render to appropriate pay offices for incorporation; 'end of month' means date of last payment to Sub-Accounting Officer.
option_d: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
explanation: FR 1221 requires: Monthly certified returns of receipt/licence stock and use must show serial numbers at start, received, issued, and unused at end; revenue collectors render to appropriate pay offices for incorporation; 'end of month' means date of last payment to Sub-Accounting Officer.

question_text: Which option correctly applies FR 1222 in practice?
option_a: If no receipts/licences are issued in a month, a nil monthly return must still be submitted while a book is held.
option_b: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_c: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_d: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
explanation: FR 1222 requires: If no receipts/licences are issued in a month, a nil monthly return must still be submitted while a book is held.

question_text: FR 1223 sets a rule that an officer must follow. Which is it?
option_a: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_b: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_c: Unused receipt and licence booklets must be returned to the Accountant-General or Accounting Officer and the Auditor-General informed.
option_d: The action is optional and may be done at the officerâs discretion.
explanation: FR 1223 requires: Unused receipt and licence booklets must be returned to the Accountant-General or Accounting Officer and the Auditor-General informed.

question_text: Under FR 1224, which action is required to comply?
option_a: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_b: A certified true copy of a lost original receipt leaflet may be issued by the Accountant-General/Accounting Officer, supported by a sworn affidavit.
option_c: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_d: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
explanation: FR 1224 requires: A certified true copy of a lost original receipt leaflet may be issued by the Accountant-General/Accounting Officer, supported by a sworn affidavit.

question_text: Which option correctly applies FR 1225 in practice?
option_a: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_b: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_c: Any loss of receipt/licence leaflet must be investigated and reported immediately; the report goes to the Accountant-General (copy to Auditor-General) so missing particulars can be published in the official gazette (without AG approval).
option_d: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
explanation: FR 1225 requires: Any loss of receipt/licence leaflet must be investigated and reported immediately; the report goes to the Accountant-General (copy to Auditor-General) so missing particulars can be published in the official gazette (without AG approval).

question_text: FR 1226 sets a rule that an officer must follow. Which is it?
option_a: On handover, both officers must sign certificates covering all receipt/licence books on charge, supported by detailed list of quantities and serial numbers; taking-over officer signs below last stock register entries.
option_b: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_c: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_d: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
explanation: FR 1226 requires: On handover, both officers must sign certificates covering all receipt/licence books on charge, supported by detailed list of quantities and serial numbers; taking-over officer signs below last stock register entries.

question_text: Under FR 1227, which action is required to comply?
option_a: Audited fixed-fee licences/tickets counterfoils may be destroyed two years after the date of issue of the last receipt in them.
option_b: Unused/obsolete receipts may be destroyed by a single officer without documentation.
option_c: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_d: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
explanation: FR 1227 requires: Audited fixed-fee licences/tickets counterfoils may be destroyed two years after the date of issue of the last receipt in them.

question_text: Which option correctly applies FR 1228 in practice?
option_a: Obsolete unused receipts/licences may be destroyed by burning in presence of three senior officers (two from outside Finance/Accounts) after checks; destruction certificate signed and sent to Auditor-General; stock registers updated; Auditor-General notified in advance.
option_b: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_c: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_d: Unused/obsolete receipts may be destroyed by a single officer without documentation.
explanation: FR 1228 requires: Obsolete unused receipts/licences may be destroyed by burning in presence of three senior officers (two from outside Finance/Accounts) after checks; destruction certificate signed and sent to Auditor-General; stock registers updated; Auditor-General notified in advance.

question_text: FR 1301 sets a rule that an officer must follow. Which is it?
option_a: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_b: The action is optional and may be done at the officerâs discretion.
option_c: Deposits must be accounted for under the Below-the-line classification list issued by the Accountant-General.
option_d: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
explanation: FR 1301 requires: Deposits must be accounted for under the Below-the-line classification list issued by the Accountant-General.

question_text: Which option correctly applies FR 1303 in practice?
option_a: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_b: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_c: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_d: Accounting Officers must include deposit-account operating instructions in their accounting codes, subject to Accountant-General approval after consultation with the Auditor-General.
explanation: FR 1303 requires: Accounting Officers must include deposit-account operating instructions in their accounting codes, subject to Accountant-General approval after consultation with the Auditor-General.

question_text: FR 1304 sets a rule that an officer must follow. Which is it?
option_a: A deposit register must be maintained to record all deposit transactions, including depositor name and details of deposits/withdrawals, posted promptly with sufficient identification detail.
option_b: The action is optional and may be done at the officerâs discretion.
option_c: Deposits may be repaid at any station if the payee presents identification.
option_d: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
explanation: FR 1304 requires: A deposit register must be maintained to record all deposit transactions, including depositor name and details of deposits/withdrawals, posted promptly with sufficient identification detail.

question_text: Under FR 1305, which action is required to comply?
option_a: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_b: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_c: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_d: Deposit receipt vouchers must state on whose behalf the deposit is made, the nature of the transaction, and why the sum is placed on deposit.
explanation: FR 1305 requires: Deposit receipt vouchers must state on whose behalf the deposit is made, the nature of the transaction, and why the sum is placed on deposit.

question_text: Which option correctly applies FR 1306 in practice?
option_a: Deposits may be repaid at any station if the payee presents identification.
option_b: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_c: Deposit withdrawals must be supported by the original deposit receipt; on withdrawal it is marked 'repaid' and attached; for part withdrawals, withdraw the whole then re-deposit the unrequired balance with a new receipt.
option_d: The action is optional and may be done at the officerâs discretion.
explanation: FR 1306 requires: Deposit withdrawals must be supported by the original deposit receipt; on withdrawal it is marked 'repaid' and attached; for part withdrawals, withdraw the whole then re-deposit the unrequired balance with a new receipt.

question_text: FR 1307 sets a rule that an officer must follow. Which is it?
option_a: A deposit must not be repaid at an office other than where it was received.
option_b: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_c: The action is optional and may be done at the officerâs discretion.
option_d: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
explanation: FR 1307 requires: A deposit must not be repaid at an office other than where it was received.

question_text: Under FR 1308, which action is required to comply?
option_a: At financial year end, the Director of Finance and Accounts compiles a certified list of unwithdrawn deposits (certified by Internal Audit) and forwards it to the Accountant-General for refund at the start of the new year.
option_b: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_c: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_d: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
explanation: FR 1308 requires: At financial year end, the Director of Finance and Accounts compiles a certified list of unwithdrawn deposits (certified by Internal Audit) and forwards it to the Accountant-General for refund at the start of the new year.

question_text: Which option correctly applies FR 1309 in practice?
option_a: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_b: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_c: Deposits over two years old (except prisonersâ property) must not be repaid without prior approval of the Accounting Officer.
option_d: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
explanation: FR 1309 requires: Deposits over two years old (except prisonersâ property) must not be repaid without prior approval of the Accounting Officer.

question_text: FR 1310 sets a rule that an officer must follow. Which is it?
option_a: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_b: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_c: The action is optional and may be done at the officerâs discretion.
option_d: Non-prisoner deposits unclaimed for five years or more must be reported to the Accountant-General with details; with authority, they may be transferred to revenue via adjustment voucher, recorded with voucher particulars.
explanation: FR 1310 requires: Non-prisoner deposits unclaimed for five years or more must be reported to the Accountant-General with details; with authority, they may be transferred to revenue via adjustment voucher, recorded with voucher particulars.

question_text: Under FR 1311, which action is required to comply?
option_a: The action is optional and may be done at the officerâs discretion.
option_b: Refunds of Immigration Restriction Act deposits require authority of the Accounting Officer of the Ministry of Interior; authority must be attached to voucher and referenced.
option_c: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_d: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
explanation: FR 1311 requires: Refunds of Immigration Restriction Act deposits require authority of the Accounting Officer of the Ministry of Interior; authority must be attached to voucher and referenced.

question_text: Which option correctly applies FR 1312 in practice?
option_a: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_b: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_c: Accounting Officers must reconcile monthly deposit ledger balances with schedules provided by the Accountant-General.
option_d: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
explanation: FR 1312 requires: Accounting Officers must reconcile monthly deposit ledger balances with schedules provided by the Accountant-General.

question_text: FR 1313 sets a rule that an officer must follow. Which is it?
option_a: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_b: The action is optional and may be done at the officerâs discretion.
option_c: Deposit ledgers must be balanced and ruled off at financial year end, carrying down outstanding balances with adequate cross-references.
option_d: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
explanation: FR 1313 requires: Deposit ledgers must be balanced and ruled off at financial year end, carrying down outstanding balances with adequate cross-references.

question_text: In applying FR 1401, which of the following should happen?
option_a: An imprest issued for routine office expenditure, repayable only at year-end.
option_b: A deposit held below-the-line for third parties and refundable on demand.
option_c: A cash loan to an individual federal officer, grantable only under the Financial Regulations and Public Service Rules.
option_d: Any advance to an officer, whether personal or official, authorised solely by the Accountant-General.
explanation: FR 1401 limits personal advances to cash loans to individual officers and restricts them to the authority of the Financial Regulations and Public Service Rules.

question_text: A supervisor wants to follow FR 1402. Which is the correct step?
option_a: A revenue refund mechanism that must always be approved by the Auditor-General.
option_b: A cash loan to an officer for private needs, approved by any Head of Department without limits.
option_c: Any advance above ?50,000 that can be approved by the Accounting Officer without exception.
option_d: An official-capacity advance (e.g., imprest/loss-of-funds), generally requiring Minister of Finance approval except FR 2524 cases or up to ?50,000 approved by the Accounting Officer, with applications stating reason, clearance method, and responsible person.
explanation: FR 1402 defines non-personal advances and sets approval rules (Minister of Finance, with stated exceptions), plus application content and project governance.

question_text: A supervisor wants to follow FR 1403. Which is the correct step?
option_a: Only the cheque number and bank account designation.
option_b: Only the vote book sub-head and the paying station code.
option_c: Officers name/designation, below-the-line classification code, nature of advance, recovery terms, and authority for the advance.
option_d: Only the suppliers invoice reference and LPO number.
explanation: FR 1403 specifies the mandatory particulars that must appear on vouchers relating to advances.

question_text: Which option reflects the correct rule in FR 1404 when applying it to a typical case?
option_a: Delegate advance ledger control entirely to the cashier without review.
option_b: Maintain fully indexed advance account records, post transactions promptly, reconcile monthly with the Accountant-Generals control, and flag overdue items to the Accounting Officer.
option_c: Record advances only at year-end and reconcile only during external audit.
option_d: Keep advance records unindexed and reconcile only when a query is raised.
explanation: FR 1404 sets record-keeping, timeliness, reconciliation, and monitoring requirements for advance accounts.

question_text: Which option reflects the correct rule in FR 1405 when applying it to a typical case?
option_a: Ensure advances are converted to deposits when repayment delays occur.
option_b: Ensure advances are written off automatically after one year.
option_c: Ensure advances are charged to revenue heads until recovered.
option_d: Ensure advances are repaid promptly, whether by instalments or otherwise.
explanation: FR 1405 assigns Accounting Officers responsibility for prompt repayment of all advances.

question_text: An officer cites FR 1406. Which action is compliant with the regulation?
option_a: Grant advance only after the officer returns and submits vouchers.
option_b: Grant up to one months salary advance to an officer on transfer who bears transport costs wholly or partly.
option_c: Grant up to three months salary advance automatically to any transferring officer.
option_d: Grant an imprest instead of a salary advance for family transport costs.
explanation: FR 1406 allows a salary advance on transfer, capped at one months salary, tied to transport costs borne by the officer.

question_text: A supervisor wants to follow FR 1407. Which is the correct step?
option_a: Approve an estacode advance up to three months salary for any overseas posting.
option_b: Approve payment only through deposits, not salary advances.
option_c: Approve an advance only if the officer is GL.15 and above.
option_d: Approve a salary advance up to one months salary for an officer posted to an overseas office/duty.
explanation: FR 1407 provides for a salary advance of up to one months salary for overseas posting.

question_text: An officer cites FR 1408. Which action is compliant with the regulation?
option_a: Grant temporary appointees salary advances without any guarantee requirement.
option_b: Grant two months salary to all first appointees as entitlement.
option_c: On first appointment, grant up to one months salary; for temporary appointment, grant up to one months salary only with an acceptable guarantee.
option_d: Grant advances only after confirmation of appointment.
explanation: FR 1408 sets limits for first appointment and adds a guarantee condition for temporary appointments.

question_text: An officer cites FR 1409. Which action is compliant with the regulation?
option_a: Repay 1-month advance over 6 instalments and allow deductions up to 75% of salary.
option_b: Repay 3-month advance over 12 instalments and start deductions immediately in the same month.
option_c: Repay 1-month advance in 3 equal consecutive instalments starting next month; 2- and 3-month advances in up to 6 and 9 instalments; total deductions must not exceed half monthly salary.
option_d: Repay all salary advances in a single lump sum within 30 days, regardless of amount.
explanation: FR 1409 fixes instalment lengths by advance size and caps total deductions at not more than half of monthly salary.

question_text: Which option reflects the correct rule in FR 1410 when applying it to a typical case?
option_a: Classify salary advances and recoveries to the below-the-line advance account in the officers name, not to personal emoluments.
option_b: Classify recoveries to revenue heads and advances to overhead cost vote.
option_c: Classify salary advances to personal emoluments vote to simplify reconciliation.
option_d: Classify advances to capital sub-heads and recoveries to suspense accounts.
explanation: FR 1410 is a classification rule: below-the-line advance account in the officers name; never personal emoluments vote.

question_text: Which option reflects the correct rule in FR 1411 when applying it to a typical case?
option_a: Local DTA per diem rates by cadre (?35,000; ?20,000; ?16,000; ?12,000; ?5,000) with ?20/km transport where no air, plus 30% local running; only for approved tours; charge direct to vote without retirement.
option_b: Per diem excludes feeding and is payable only after audit clearance; transport is per-mile at a fixed dollar rate.
option_c: Per diem rates are set by each ministry quarterly and must be retired to deposit accounts.
option_d: Uniform ?10,000 per diem for all grades, with retirement required within 48 hours.
explanation: FR 1411 sets specific per diem and transport rules for duty tours within Nigeria, plus charging and approval conditions.

question_text: In applying FR 1412, which of the following should happen?
option_a: Estacode rates are uniform at $300 per diem regardless of grade.
option_b: Accounting Officer authorises estacode at prevailing rates: $900, $600, $425, $381, $206 per diem by cadre.
option_c: Estacode is paid only after return from travel and must be retired like an imprest.
option_d: Estacode is authorised by the Auditor-General and paid as a fixed monthly allowance.
explanation: FR 1412 specifies that the Accounting Officer authorises estacode and provides the grade-based per diem rates.

question_text: Which option reflects the correct rule in FR 1413 when applying it to a typical case?
option_a: Pay additional estacode automatically if the officer overstays, without refund obligation.
option_b: Pay estacode in cash abroad from mission revenue accounts without approvals.
option_c: Issue estacode as bank drafts payable to the mission and later reallocate by journal entry.
option_d: Draw estacode in Nigeria as travellers cheques payable to the officer(s) from CBN; extra estacode by mission requires Accounting Officer approval and must be refunded by the ministry/agency.
explanation: FR 1413 prescribes the instrument (travellers cheques), source (CBN), and approval/refund rules for additional estacode.

question_text: An officer cites FR 1414. Which action is compliant with the regulation?
option_a: Overstay is allowed for GL.15 and above without further approvals.
option_b: Overstay is allowed if the officer uses personal funds for extra days.
option_c: Do not overstay the approved number of days on duty tour without prior Accounting Officer approval.
option_d: Overstay is allowed if the officer sends an email to the paying officer after the fact.
explanation: FR 1414 is a strict approval rule: no overstaying locally or overseas without prior Accounting Officer approval.

question_text: Which option reflects the correct rule in FR 1415 when applying it to a typical case?
option_a: Allow advances for any course, including unrelated hobbies, and include exam/other fees.
option_b: Charge interest on the advance and recover over any period the officer requests.
option_c: Authorise only if conditions are met: work-related, efficiency benefit, reputable institution, receipts produced, TF51 repayment agreement (+ surety if <2 years service), interest-free, excludes postage/stationery/exam fees, recover within 24 instalments.
option_d: Approve without agreement forms provided the officer promises to repay verbally.
explanation: FR 1415 lists strict eligibility, documentation (TF51/surety), cost exclusions, and recovery limits for study-related advances.

question_text: In applying FR 1416, which of the following should happen?
option_a: Recover the outstanding balance in full from the officers last salary and/or retirement gratuity on exit.
option_b: Write off the balance when an officer resigns if more than half has been recovered.
option_c: Suspend recovery until the next financial year to avoid excess expenditure.
option_d: Transfer the balance to revenue once the officer leaves.
explanation: FR 1416 mandates full recovery of any outstanding advance balance from final salary and/or gratuity upon leaving service.

question_text: An officer cites FR 1417. Which action is compliant with the regulation?
option_a: Convert the balance to a deposit and hold for five years before transfer to revenue.
option_b: Recover from next of kins salary if employed in government.
option_c: Recover from the estate in all cases, regardless of gratuity entitlement.
option_d: Do not recover the outstanding salary advance balance from the estate where the deceased officer is not entitled to gratuity; government bears the irrecoverable balance.
explanation: FR 1417 creates a specific exception: if no gratuity entitlement, the estate is not charged; government accepts liability.

question_text: Which option reflects the correct rule in FR 1418 when applying it to a typical case?
option_a: Close the advance ledger at the old station and restart recovery from zero at the new station.
option_b: State advance details and recoveries in the Last Pay Certificate sent to the new station with certified true Personal Emolument Record; new station SAO records the balance and continues recovery.
option_c: Convert the outstanding balance to an imprest at the new station.
option_d: Send only a verbal handover note; the Personal Emolument Record is not required.
explanation: FR 1418 establishes the documentation and continuity steps for recovering advances after transfer to a new pay station.

question_text: Which option reflects the correct rule in FR 1419 when applying it to a typical case?
option_a: If advice is missing, instalments are waived automatically.
option_b: If advice is missing, recoveries must wait until the officer requests deduction.
option_c: The absence of advice does not excuse non-repayment; missed instalments are deducted en bloc once the appropriate documents arrive.
option_d: If advice is missing, convert the instalments to interest-bearing debt.
explanation: FR 1419 makes repayment obligatory regardless of advice and permits en bloc deduction of missed instalments once documentation is received.

question_text: Which option reflects the correct rule in FR 1420 when applying it to a typical case?
option_a: Ensure that all advances granted are fully recovered.
option_b: Ensure advances are classified to overhead votes to simplify budgeting.
option_c: Ensure advances are issued promptly even if recovery systems are not in place.
option_d: Ensure advances are retired only at the end of the officers career.
explanation: FR 1420 states the Accounting Officers overarching duty: complete recovery of all advances.

question_text: Which situation best reflects FR 1501 requirements?
option_a: It is enforced only after complaints
option_b: Compliance must follow the specific provision stated in FR 1501
option_c: It is optional unless approved by junior officers
option_d: It applies only during audits
explanation: FR 1501 explicitly requires adherence to its stated rule.

option_a: Compliance must follow the specific provision stated in FR 1502
option_b: It is enforced only after complaints
option_c: It applies only during audits
option_d: It is limited to external contractors

option_d: Compliance must follow the specific provision stated in FR 1528
explanation: FR 1528 explicitly requires adherence to its stated rule.

question_text: From an application standpoint, FR 1529 implies that:
option_a: It is discretionary for departments
option_b: Compliance must follow the specific provision stated in FR 1529
option_c: It is enforced only after complaints
option_d: It is required only for temporary staff
explanation: FR 1529 explicitly requires adherence to its stated rule.

question_text: Which authority must a selfâaccounting unit report to periodically?
option_a: AuditorâGeneral
option_b: AccountantâGeneral
option_c: Minister of Finance
option_d: Budget Office
explanation: They must account to the AccountantâGeneral monthly and annually.

question_text: Which is a prerequisite condition?
option_a: Transport allowance policy
option_b: Internal Audit Unit
option_c: Public relations unit
option_d: Training manual
explanation: A fully constituted Internal Audit Unit is required.

question_text: This arrangement is done in consultation with whom?
option_a: Minister
option_b: Auditor
option_c: AccountantâGeneral
option_d: Governor
explanation: It must be done with AG.

question_text: Which document must be examined for correctness?
option_a: Leave forms
option_b: Summary vouchers
option_c: ID cards
option_d: Memos
explanation: They must examine vouchers.

question_text: Charges to votes must be supported by:
option_a: Emails
option_b: Original documents and receipts
option_c: Phone calls
option_d: Draft notes
explanation: Original evidence required.

question_text: Which record must be preserved?
option_a: Attendance sheet
option_b: Cash books
option_c: Invitation cards
option_d: Minutes
explanation: Cash books required.

question_text: Schedule must include which detail?
option_a: Weather
option_b: Voucher reference
option_c: Dress code
option_d: Lunch time
explanation: Voucher reference required.

question_text: Discrepancies must be reported to:
option_a: Police
option_b: AccountantâGeneral
option_c: Clerk
option_d: Union
explanation: They must notify AG.

question_text: External payments require what instrument?
option_a: Memo
option_b: Departmental Warrant
option_c: Letter
option_d: Circular
explanation: AIE required.

question_text: Status may be withdrawn if unit:
option_a: Requests it
option_b: Fails compliance
option_c: Expands
option_d: Relocates
explanation: Nonâcompliance triggers withdrawal.

question_text: A unit applies FR 1701 on Internal Audit meaning and responsibility. Which action is compliant?
option_a: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_b: Internal Audit is a managerial control that measures/evaluates effectiveness of Internal Control system
option_c: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_d: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
explanation: FR 1701 emphasises that Internal Audit is a managerial control that measures/evaluates effectiveness of Internal Control system.

question_text: Which option correctly interprets FR 1702 in handling Placement of competent accountant for IA units?
option_a: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_b: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_c: Accountant-General ensures suitably competent Accountant placed directly in charge of Internal Audit Units
option_d: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
explanation: FR 1702 emphasises that Accountant-General ensures suitably competent Accountant placed directly in charge of Internal Audit Units.

question_text: A staff member suggests a step under FR 1703 for Reporting lines and programme of audit. Which step is correct?
option_a: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_b: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_c: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_d: Issues special reports on irregularity, procedure weakness, inattention to Auditor-General reports, or earlier IA reports
explanation: FR 1703 emphasises that Issues special reports on irregularity, procedure weakness, inattention to Auditor-General reports, or earlier IA reports.

question_text: Which compliance step best aligns with FR 1704 on Annual audit programme scope?
option_a: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_b: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_c: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_d: Programme covers safeguards against fraud/loss, revenue control, expenditure control, stores control, verification of cash/stores/assets, accuracy of records
explanation: FR 1704 emphasises that Programme covers safeguards against fraud/loss, revenue control, expenditure control, stores control, verification of cash/stores/assets, accuracy of records.

question_text: A unit applies FR 1705 on Pre-payment audit and 48-hour rule. Which action is compliant?
option_a: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_b: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_c: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_d: Vouchers must not be held in IA Unit for more than 48 hours
explanation: FR 1705 emphasises that Vouchers must not be held in IA Unit for more than 48 hours.

question_text: Which option correctly interprets FR 1706 in handling Periodic IA reports and content?
option_a: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_b: Internal Audit reports are submitted only annually, not monthly/quarterly/half-yearly.
option_c: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_d: IA produces monthly, quarterly and half-yearly reports to Accounting Officer with copies to AG and Auditor-General
explanation: FR 1706 emphasises that IA produces monthly, quarterly and half-yearly reports to Accounting Officer with copies to AG and Auditor-General.

question_text: A staff member suggests a step under FR 1707 for Register to track audit progress. Which step is correct?
option_a: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_b: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_c: Head IA maintains under personal control a register to record progress of the audit
option_d: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
explanation: FR 1707 emphasises that Head IA maintains under personal control a register to record progress of the audit.

question_text: Which compliance step best aligns with FR 1708 on Internal audit instructions?
option_a: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_b: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_c: Explain nature of accounts relative to ministry function; references to law and relevant accounting instructions
option_d: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
explanation: FR 1708 emphasises that Explain nature of accounts relative to ministry function; references to law and relevant accounting instructions.

question_text: A unit applies FR 1709 on Independence of IA staff. Which action is compliant?
option_a: IA staff shall not be employed on accounting duties within the ministry/unit
option_b: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_c: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_d: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
explanation: FR 1709 emphasises that IA staff shall not be employed on accounting duties within the ministry/unit.

question_text: Which option correctly interprets FR 1710 in handling Internal audit stamps as security instruments?
option_a: All IA stamps issued by Accountant-General and treated as security instruments
option_b: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_c: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_d: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
explanation: FR 1710 emphasises that All IA stamps issued by Accountant-General and treated as security instruments.

question_text: A staff member suggests a step under FR 1711 for Eligibility and application for audit stamps. Which step is correct?
option_a: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_b: Application signed by Head IA and countersigned by Accounting Officer; Head IA collects stamps from AG
option_c: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_d: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
explanation: FR 1711 emphasises that Application signed by Head IA and countersigned by Accounting Officer; Head IA collects stamps from AG.

question_text: Which compliance step best aligns with FR 1712 on Daily custody and register for audit stamps?
option_a: Head IA collects all audit stamps end of each day; locks in Treasury Safe with two senior officers holding keys (one being Head IA)
option_b: Audit stamps may be left with each user overnight if kept in a locked drawer.
option_c: Daily issue/return need not be recorded if stamps are numbered.
option_d: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
explanation: FR 1712 emphasises that Head IA collects all audit stamps end of each day; locks in Treasury Safe with two senior officers holding keys (one being Head IA).

question_text: A unit applies FR 1713 on Non-transferability and return of stamps. Which action is compliant?
option_a: Returned stamps may be re-issued to another officer after endorsement by Head of Internal Audit.
option_b: Audit stamps can be transferred to a colleague on the same grade level.
option_c: Audit stamps are not transferable
option_d: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
explanation: FR 1713 emphasises that Audit stamps are not transferable.

question_text: Which option correctly interprets FR 1714 in handling Sanctions for loss of audit stamp?
option_a: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_b: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_c: Replacement cost is borne by the ministry, not the officer, in all cases.
option_d: Internal auditor who loses an audit stamp through negligence bears maximum penalty of surcharge or replacement cost as confirmed by Accountant-General
explanation: FR 1714 emphasises that Internal auditor who loses an audit stamp through negligence bears maximum penalty of surcharge or replacement cost as confirmed by Accountant-General.

question_text: A staff member suggests a step under FR 1715 for Access rights of Internal Auditor. Which step is correct?
option_a: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_b: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_c: Internal Auditor has free access at reasonable times to stores and store records for independent audit
option_d: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
explanation: FR 1715 emphasises that Internal Auditor has free access at reasonable times to stores and store records for independent audit.

question_text: Which compliance step best aligns with FR 1801 on Annual boards of survey (domestic)?
option_a: Annual Boards of Survey are convened by the Auditor-General rather than Treasury Inspectorate.
option_b: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
option_c: Cash transactions may continue during a survey provided they are recorded in the cash book.
option_d: Director, Treasury Inspectorate Dept (OAGF) convenes annual boards; calls for cash offices list by first week Aug; Accounting Officers send info by first week Oct; Director appoints members and advises AOs
explanation: FR 1801 emphasises that Director, Treasury Inspectorate Dept (OAGF) convenes annual boards; calls for cash offices list by first week Aug; Accounting Officers send info by first week Oct; Director appoints members and advises AOs.

question_text: A unit applies FR 1802 on Annual boards of survey (missions overseas). Which action is compliant?
option_a: Reports of Boards of Survey may be submitted within six weeks after the survey.
option_b: Annual boards for missions overseas on cash/bank/stamps held; Head of Mission convenes
option_c: Annual surveys for missions overseas are convened by the Accountant-General, not Heads of Mission.
option_d: Treasury Inspectorate calls for mission survey returns in January, not August.
explanation: FR 1802 emphasises that Annual boards for missions overseas on cash/bank/stamps held; Head of Mission convenes.

question_text: Which option correctly interprets FR 1803 in handling Surprise boards of survey (domestic)?
option_a: A Board of Survey may be constituted with members below GL.08 if supervised.
option_b: Director and authorised officers may make surprise inspections; appointment kept confidential
option_c: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
option_d: Boards of Survey are held only at the end of each quarter, not at year-end.
explanation: FR 1803 emphasises that Director and authorised officers may make surprise inspections; appointment kept confidential.

question_text: A staff member suggests a step under FR 1804 for Surprise boards of survey (missions overseas). Which step is correct?
option_a: Cash transactions may continue during a survey provided they are recorded in the cash book.
option_b: Surprise boards at missions overseas three times each year; Head of Mission convenes; held at intervals as 1803
option_c: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
option_d: Boards of Survey are held only at the end of each quarter, not at year-end.
explanation: FR 1804 emphasises that Surprise boards at missions overseas three times each year; Head of Mission convenes; held at intervals as 1803.

question_text: Which compliance step best aligns with FR 1805 on Composition and conduct of board?
option_a: Boards of Survey are held only at the end of each quarter, not at year-end.
option_b: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
option_c: Board consists of three officers including President
option_d: Cash transactions may continue during a survey provided they are recorded in the cash book.
explanation: FR 1805 emphasises that Board consists of three officers including President.

question_text: A unit applies FR 1806 on Suspension of cash transactions during survey. Which action is compliant?
option_a: Unverified cash may be kept in the cashierâs drawer if the safe is full.
option_b: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
option_c: If survey not completed in one day, unverified cash kept separately in safe
option_d: Cash transactions may continue during a survey provided they are recorded in the cash book.
explanation: FR 1806 emphasises that If survey not completed in one day, unverified cash kept separately in safe.

question_text: Which option correctly interprets FR 1807 in handling Certification and treatment of surplus/shortage?
option_a: Shortages discovered must always be written off as sundries immediately.
option_b: Boards of Survey are held only at the end of each quarter, not at year-end.
option_c: Certify cash balance on original and duplicate cash book
option_d: A Board of Survey may be constituted with members below GL.08 if supervised.
explanation: FR 1807 emphasises that Certify cash balance on original and duplicate cash book.

question_text: A staff member suggests a step under FR 1808 for Board report TF42 and timelines. Which step is correct?
option_a: A Board of Survey may be constituted with members below GL.08 if supervised.
option_b: Cash transactions may continue during a survey provided they are recorded in the cash book.
option_c: President forwards not later than two weeks after survey to AG who transmits copies to Auditor-General and Accounting Officer
option_d: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
explanation: FR 1808 emphasises that President forwards not later than two weeks after survey to AG who transmits copies to Auditor-General and Accounting Officer.

question_text: Which compliance step best aligns with FR 1809 on Irregular inspections by Accounting Officers?
option_a: Inspection records are optional if no discrepancies are found.
option_b: Accounting Officers issue instructions for systematic inspection at irregular intervals of cash held by subordinate officers; record kept
option_c: Cash transactions may continue during a survey provided they are recorded in the cash book.
option_d: Reports of Boards of Survey may be submitted within six weeks after the survey.
explanation: FR 1809 emphasises that Accounting Officers issue instructions for systematic inspection at irregular intervals of cash held by subordinate officers; record kept.
