question_text: As senior management, which oversight duty on Internal Audit meaning and responsibility is required by FR 1701?
option_a: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_b: Accounting Officer ensures Internal Audit Unit is established for continuous audit of accounts/records: revenue, expenditure, assets, stores
option_c: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_d: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
explanation: FR 1701 emphasises that Accounting Officer ensures Internal Audit Unit is established for continuous audit of accounts/records: revenue, expenditure, assets, stores.

question_text: Which management decision best fulfils FR 1702 responsibilities for Placement of competent accountant for IA units?
option_a: Accountant-General ensures suitably competent Accountant placed directly in charge of Internal Audit Units
option_b: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_c: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_d: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
explanation: FR 1702 emphasises that Accountant-General ensures suitably competent Accountant placed directly in charge of Internal Audit Units.

question_text: Which supervisory control should be enforced to comply with FR 1703 on Reporting lines and programme of audit?
option_a: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_b: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_c: Issues special reports on irregularity, procedure weakness, inattention to Auditor-General reports, or earlier IA reports
option_d: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
explanation: FR 1703 emphasises that Issues special reports on irregularity, procedure weakness, inattention to Auditor-General reports, or earlier IA reports.

question_text: Which governance instruction should management issue to align with FR 1704 on Annual audit programme scope?
option_a: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_b: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_c: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_d: Programme covers safeguards against fraud/loss, revenue control, expenditure control, stores control, verification of cash/stores/assets, accuracy of records
explanation: FR 1704 emphasises that Programme covers safeguards against fraud/loss, revenue control, expenditure control, stores control, verification of cash/stores/assets, accuracy of records.

question_text: As senior management, which oversight duty on Pre-payment audit and 48-hour rule is required by FR 1705?
option_a: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_b: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_c: Head IA ensures 100% pre-payment audit of all checked and passed vouchers
option_d: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
explanation: FR 1705 emphasises that Head IA ensures 100% pre-payment audit of all checked and passed vouchers.

question_text: Which management decision best fulfils FR 1706 responsibilities for Periodic IA reports and content?
option_a: IA produces monthly, quarterly and half-yearly reports to Accounting Officer with copies to AG and Auditor-General
option_b: Internal Audit reports are submitted only annually, not monthly/quarterly/half-yearly.
option_c: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_d: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
explanation: FR 1706 emphasises that IA produces monthly, quarterly and half-yearly reports to Accounting Officer with copies to AG and Auditor-General.

question_text: Which supervisory control should be enforced to comply with FR 1707 on Register to track audit progress?
option_a: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_b: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_c: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_d: Head IA maintains under personal control a register to record progress of the audit
explanation: FR 1707 emphasises that Head IA maintains under personal control a register to record progress of the audit.

question_text: Which governance instruction should management issue to align with FR 1708 on Internal audit instructions?
option_a: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_b: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_c: Head IA draws up detailed IA instructions for staff; comprehensive amplification of audit guide
option_d: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
explanation: FR 1708 emphasises that Head IA draws up detailed IA instructions for staff; comprehensive amplification of audit guide.

question_text: As senior management, which oversight duty on Independence of IA staff is required by FR 1709?
option_a: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_b: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_c: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_d: Officer previously engaged on accounting duties in the same ministry/unit is precluded from taking up IA duties
explanation: FR 1709 emphasises that Officer previously engaged on accounting duties in the same ministry/unit is precluded from taking up IA duties.

question_text: Which management decision best fulfils FR 1710 responsibilities for Internal audit stamps as security instruments?
option_a: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_b: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_c: IA certification is through Internal Audit stamps
option_d: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
explanation: FR 1710 emphasises that IA certification is through Internal Audit stamps.

question_text: Which supervisory control should be enforced to comply with FR 1711 on Eligibility and application for audit stamps?
option_a: Head IA submits names/particulars of staff empowered to use stamps; ranks not below GL09 in Abuja and GL08 outside Abuja
option_b: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_c: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_d: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
explanation: FR 1711 emphasises that Head IA submits names/particulars of staff empowered to use stamps; ranks not below GL09 in Abuja and GL08 outside Abuja.

question_text: Which governance instruction should management issue to align with FR 1712 on Daily custody and register for audit stamps?
option_a: Daily issue/return need not be recorded if stamps are numbered.
option_b: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_c: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_d: Outstations follow same arrangement
explanation: FR 1712 emphasises that Outstations follow same arrangement.

question_text: As senior management, which oversight duty on Non-transferability and return of stamps is required by FR 1713?
option_a: Re-assigned auditors return stamps to Head IA; Head IA forwards to AG and informs Accounting Officer; stamps must not be re-issued
option_b: Returned stamps may be re-issued to another officer after endorsement by Head of Internal Audit.
option_c: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_d: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
explanation: FR 1713 emphasises that Re-assigned auditors return stamps to Head IA; Head IA forwards to AG and informs Accounting Officer; stamps must not be re-issued.

question_text: Which management decision best fulfils FR 1714 responsibilities for Sanctions for loss of audit stamp?
option_a: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_b: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_c: Internal auditor who loses an audit stamp through negligence bears maximum penalty of surcharge or replacement cost as confirmed by Accountant-General
option_d: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
explanation: FR 1714 emphasises that Internal auditor who loses an audit stamp through negligence bears maximum penalty of surcharge or replacement cost as confirmed by Accountant-General.

question_text: Which supervisory control should be enforced to comply with FR 1715 on Access rights of Internal Auditor?
option_a: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_b: Internal Auditor has free access at reasonable times to stores and store records for independent audit
option_c: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_d: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
explanation: FR 1715 emphasises that Internal Auditor has free access at reasonable times to stores and store records for independent audit.

question_text: Which governance instruction should management issue to align with FR 1801 on Annual boards of survey (domestic)?
option_a: Boards of Survey held after close of last business day or before first working day of new FY
option_b: Cash transactions may continue during a survey provided they are recorded in the cash book.
option_c: A Board of Survey may be constituted with members below GL.08 if supervised.
option_d: Annual Boards of Survey are convened by the Auditor-General rather than Treasury Inspectorate.
explanation: FR 1801 emphasises that Boards of Survey held after close of last business day or before first working day of new FY.

question_text: As senior management, which oversight duty on Annual boards of survey (missions overseas) is required by FR 1802?
option_a: Cash transactions may continue during a survey provided they are recorded in the cash book.
option_b: Boards of Survey are held only at the end of each quarter, not at year-end.
option_c: A Board of Survey may be constituted with members below GL.08 if supervised.
option_d: Director Treasury Inspectorate by first week Aug writes to MFA to ensure compliance
explanation: FR 1802 emphasises that Director Treasury Inspectorate by first week Aug writes to MFA to ensure compliance.

question_text: Which management decision best fulfils FR 1803 responsibilities for Surprise boards of survey (domestic)?
option_a: The appointment of surprise Boards may be openly announced for transparency.
option_b: Surprise Boards are held only at the end of each quarter.
option_c: Boards of Survey are held only at the end of each quarter, not at year-end.
option_d: Once in each of first three quarters; not necessarily end of month/quarter
explanation: FR 1803 emphasises that Once in each of first three quarters; not necessarily end of month/quarter.

question_text: Which supervisory control should be enforced to comply with FR 1804 on Surprise boards of survey (missions overseas)?
option_a: Boards of Survey are held only at the end of each quarter, not at year-end.
option_b: Cash transactions may continue during a survey provided they are recorded in the cash book.
option_c: Surprise boards at missions overseas three times each year; Head of Mission convenes; held at intervals as 1803
option_d: A Board of Survey may be constituted with members below GL.08 if supervised.
explanation: FR 1804 emphasises that Surprise boards at missions overseas three times each year; Head of Mission convenes; held at intervals as 1803.

question_text: Which governance instruction should management issue to align with FR 1805 on Composition and conduct of board?
option_a: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
option_b: Reports of Boards of Survey may be submitted within six weeks after the survey.
option_c: Members unable to serve must report immediately to convening authority
option_d: Cash transactions may continue during a survey provided they are recorded in the cash book.
explanation: FR 1805 emphasises that Members unable to serve must report immediately to convening authority.

question_text: As senior management, which oversight duty on Suspension of cash transactions during survey is required by FR 1806?
option_a: Boards of Survey are held only at the end of each quarter, not at year-end.
option_b: No cash transactions between year-end close and time of survey
option_c: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
option_d: Cash transactions may occur between year-end close and survey if countersigned by the Board.
explanation: FR 1806 emphasises that No cash transactions between year-end close and time of survey.

question_text: Which management decision best fulfils FR 1807 responsibilities for Certification and treatment of surplus/shortage?
option_a: Surplus credited to revenue head: Miscellaneous, Sub-head: Sundries; shortage made good or charged to advance for investigation; serious shortage reported immediately to AG with copy to Auditor-General per Chapter 25
option_b: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
option_c: Surpluses are credited to an advance account for later allocation.
option_d: Shortages discovered must always be written off as sundries immediately.
explanation: FR 1807 emphasises that Surplus credited to revenue head: Miscellaneous, Sub-head: Sundries; shortage made good or charged to advance for investigation; serious shortage reported immediately to AG with copy to Auditor-General per Chapter 25.

question_text: Which supervisory control should be enforced to comply with FR 1808 on Board report TF42 and timelines?
option_a: On completion of survey, report in triplicate on Revised TF42 signed by all members
option_b: Cash transactions may continue during a survey provided they are recorded in the cash book.
option_c: Boards of Survey are held only at the end of each quarter, not at year-end.
option_d: A Board of Survey may be constituted with members below GL.08 if supervised.
explanation: FR 1808 emphasises that On completion of survey, report in triplicate on Revised TF42 signed by all members.

question_text: Which governance instruction should management issue to align with FR 1809 on Irregular inspections by Accounting Officers?
option_a: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
option_b: A Board of Survey may be constituted with members below GL.08 if supervised.
option_c: Boards of Survey are held only at the end of each quarter, not at year-end.
option_d: Accounting Officers issue instructions for systematic inspection at irregular intervals of cash held by subordinate officers; record kept
explanation: FR 1809 emphasises that Accounting Officers issue instructions for systematic inspection at irregular intervals of cash held by subordinate officers; record kept.

question_text: Which institutional control priority is implied by FR 718?
option_a: Cheques received must be banked by next business day; special remittance steps apply for commission cheques and cheques must not be endorsed to third parties.
option_b: Cheques must not be accepted if drawer standing is doubtful; bank guarantees should be arranged from officially listed banks where possible.
option_c: Government funds must not be placed in banks charging commissions; monthly statements must confirm no commission on turnover is charged.
option_d: Requests for official cheque books must be signed by an authorised account signatory and countersigned by the Head of Accounts.
explanation: FR 718 provides that Requests for official cheque books must be signed by an authorised account signatory and countersigned by the Head of Accounts.

question_text: Which enterprise-risk concern is reduced by FR 719?
option_a: Cheques should be payable to the Federal Government (or official designation), crossed appropriately on receipt, and accepted only after strict validity checks (including confirmation above â¦20,000).
option_b: Bills of Exchange and Promissory Notes require specific AccountantâGeneral approval before acceptance.
option_c: An officer who negligently disregards cheque acceptance checks and receives a dishonoured cheque is surcharged for the full amount.
option_d: Government funds must not be placed in banks charging commissions; monthly statements must confirm no commission on turnover is charged.
explanation: FR 719 provides that Cheques should be payable to the Federal Government (or official designation), crossed appropriately on receipt, and accepted only after strict validity checks (including confirmation above â¦20,000).

question_text: Which governance objective is central to FR 720?
option_a: An officer who negligently disregards cheque acceptance checks and receives a dishonoured cheque is surcharged for the full amount.
option_b: Cheques received must be banked by next business day; special remittance steps apply for commission cheques and cheques must not be endorsed to third parties.
option_c: Officers incurring unauthorised commission charges on cheques are liable to surcharge of the amount involved.
option_d: To ensure salary payment by the 28th monthly, quarterly remittance schedules and advance preparation are required; CBN provides credit/debit advice for reconciliation.
explanation: FR 720 provides that Cheques received must be banked by next business day; special remittance steps apply for commission cheques and cheques must not be endorsed to third parties.

question_text: Strategically, FR 721 protects what?
option_a: Officers incurring unauthorised commission charges on cheques are liable to surcharge of the amount involved.
option_b: Idle funds of MDAs may only be invested in Treasury Bills in line with extant circulars.
option_c: Overhead remittances to field offices must follow AIE/cash transfer procedures, complete within 7 working days, with sanctions/interest for delays and monthly reconciliation reporting.
option_d: Cheques should be payable to the Federal Government (or official designation), crossed appropriately on receipt, and accepted only after strict validity checks (including confirmation above â¦20,000).
explanation: FR 721 provides that Overhead remittances to field offices must follow AIE/cash transfer procedures, complete within 7 working days, with sanctions/interest for delays and monthly reconciliation reporting.

explanation: FR 722 provides that To ensure salary payment by the 28th monthly, quarterly remittance schedules and advance preparation are required; CBN provides credit/debit advice for reconciliation.

question_text: From a system-wide view, what does FR 726 primarily ensure?
option_a: Officers incurring unauthorised commission charges on cheques are liable to surcharge of the amount involved.
option_b: Postâdated cheques require prior AccountantâGeneral authority before acceptance.
option_c: Dishonoured revenue cheques must be reversed to the original head, reimbursement pursued (including legal action if needed), bank nonâappearance investigated, and no Treasury receipt issued until clearance.
option_d: Dishonoured cheque debits must be cleared/refunded by next business day and must never be treated or held as cash.
explanation: FR 726 provides that Postâdated cheques require prior AccountantâGeneral authority before acceptance.

option_a: Cheques received must be banked by next business day; special remittance steps apply for commission cheques and cheques must not be endorsed to third parties.
option_b: Bills of Exchange and Promissory Notes require specific AccountantâGeneral approval before acceptance.
option_c: Cheques should be payable to the Federal Government (or official designation), crossed appropriately on receipt, and accepted only after strict validity checks (including confirmation above â¦20,000).
option_d: Idle funds of MDAs may only be invested in Treasury Bills in line with extant circulars.
explanation: FR 727 provides that Bills of Exchange and Promissory Notes require specific AccountantâGeneral approval before acceptance.

option_a: Cheques should be payable to the Federal Government (or official designation), crossed appropriately on receipt, and accepted only after strict validity checks (including confirmation above â¦20,000).

option_a: Personal cheques must not be exchanged for cash from government funds under any circumstances.
option_b: Government funds must not be placed in banks charging commissions; monthly statements must confirm no commission on turnover is charged.
option_c: Bank tellers/paying-in-slips must specify cheques/notes/coins, bear bank acknowledgment without alteration, and show the correct stamped account number.
option_d: Dishonoured cheque debits must be cleared/refunded by next business day and must never be treated or held as cash.
explanation: FR 729 provides that Personal cheques must not be exchanged for cash from government funds under any circumstances.

question_text: At top management level, FR 1101 primarily strengthens which principle?
option_a: Liquidity control and reduced cash-holding risk.
option_b: Procurement speed and vendor convenience.
option_c: Staff welfare and allowances control.
option_d: Expansion of cash-on-hand limits.
explanation: By banking excess cash promptly, the system reduces exposure to theft/loss and improves liquidity control. (FR 1101)

question_text: At top management level, FR 1102 primarily strengthens which principle?
option_a: Decentralised key ownership without oversight.
option_b: Segregation of duties for high-value custody.
option_c: Minimising record-keeping for flexibility.
option_d: Single-person custody for speed.
explanation: Dual locks with split key custody is a classic segregation-of-duties control to reduce insider risk. (FR 1102)

question_text: Which enterprise-wide governance outcome is most aligned with FR 1103?
option_a: Store daily working cash in the strong-room only during office hours.
option_b: Keep the daily cash balance on a desk in the cashierâs office.
option_c: Provide a securely fixed (built-in/attached) safe for the daily working cash balance and stamp/receipt book stocks during office hours.
option_d: Use a portable safe that can be moved home after work.
explanation: FR 1103 is about a secure safe for daily working balances during office hours, physically secured to the structure. (FR 1103)

question_text: At top management level, FR 1104 primarily strengthens which principle?
option_a: Encouraging informal cash handling.
option_b: Reducing oversight during transport.
option_c: Maximising convenience for officers.
option_d: Secure movement of cash to prevent loss and robbery.
explanation: Approved containers, official vehicles and escort reduce transit risk and enforce accountability. (FR 1104)

question_text: At top management level, FR 1105 primarily strengthens which principle?
option_a: Inspect strong-rooms periodically for vents/openings and store currency notes in lidded boxes (not loose).
option_b: Check only the locks; vents/openings are not relevant.
option_c: Store notes loose on shelves for faster counting.
option_d: Focus only on cleaning the strong-room floor monthly.
explanation: FR 1105 requires periodic physical security checks and proper storage of notes in boxes with lids. (FR 1105)

question_text: At top management level, FR 1106 primarily strengthens which principle?
option_a: Procure safes first and request specifications after delivery.
option_b: Ensure officers handling public money/stamps have proper custody facilities; obtain specifications from the Accountant-General before procuring safes/strong-rooms/cash tanks.
option_c: Provide custody facilities only if theft has already occurred.
option_d: Let each department buy any safe model without guidance.
explanation: FR 1106 places responsibility on Accounting Officers and requires AG specifications before procurement of custody equipment. (FR 1106)

question_text: From a system-wide view, what is the core control objective behind FR 1107?
option_a: Keep duplicate keys unrecorded to avoid bureaucracy.
option_b: Issue key-security instructions; keep all duplicate keys with the Accounting Officer and maintain a key register (with possible FPO custody outside Abuja by arrangement).
option_c: Allow cashiers to keep both original and duplicate keys.
option_d: Send duplicate keys home with the most trusted clerk.
explanation: FR 1107 governs key security: AO controls duplicates, register maintained; FPO custody may apply outside Abuja; MFA issues overseas rules. (FR 1107)

question_text: Strategically, FR 1108 is intended to reduce which key risk?
option_a: Give both keys to the cashier during peak periods.
option_b: Permit one officer to hold both keys to reduce delays.
option_c: Keep both keys on a hook in the strong-room.
option_d: Do not allow one officer to hold keys to both the strong-room and the safe inside it.
explanation: FR 1108 enforces segregation of key custody when a safe is inside a strong-room. (FR 1108)

question_text: From a system-wide view, what is the core control objective behind FR 1109?
option_a: Ignore missing duplicates unless a theft occurs.
option_b: Continue using the safe and âhopeâ the duplicate turns up.
option_c: Make a private duplicate key without notifying anyone.
option_d: Original key holders must confirm duplicate keys exist; if missing/untraceable, report and request lock alteration/new keys.
explanation: FR 1109 requires verification of duplicate key availability and formal action if duplicates are missing. (FR 1109)

question_text: At top management level, FR 1110 primarily strengthens which principle?
option_a: Key holders must keep keys in personal possession and are responsible for the contents; keys must not leave their possession unless officially handed over.
option_b: Lend keys to junior staff when busy.
option_c: Leave keys in a shared drawer for convenience.
option_d: Keep keys on the safe door hook after closing.
explanation: FR 1110 establishes personal custody of keys and collective responsibility for contents. (FR 1110)

question_text: Which enterprise-wide governance outcome is most aligned with FR 1111?
option_a: Speeding up daily payments.
option_b: Budget flexibility in operations.
option_c: Incident response and containment when custody controls fail.
option_d: Routine housekeeping and aesthetics.
explanation: Sealing, guarding, controlled opening and lock replacement contain risk and preserve accountability. (FR 1111)

question_text: From a system-wide view, what is the core control objective behind FR 1112?
option_a: The ministry must always bear the cost regardless of negligence.
option_b: A negligent officer who loses a government safe key may be required to pay the cost of changing the lock and new keys.
option_c: Only the police can decide who pays for lock changes.
option_d: Key losses have no financial consequences.
explanation: FR 1112 ties key-loss negligence to financial liability for lock alteration and new keys. (FR 1112)

question_text: Strategically, FR 1113 is intended to reduce which key risk?
option_a: Ask a technician to âtightenâ the lock without reporting.
option_b: Continue using the safe but increase counting frequency.
option_c: If interference is suspected, move contents to another safe, report as in FR 1111, and request immediate lock alteration/new keys; notify other key holders.
option_d: Wait to see if anything goes missing before acting.
explanation: FR 1113 is a âsuspected compromiseâ protocol: relocate contents, report, change locks, notify key holders. (FR 1113)

question_text: Which enterprise-wide governance outcome is most aligned with FR 1114?
option_a: Any clerk may change locks as long as receipts are kept.
option_b: A contractor may do it without supervision.
option_c: Locks can be changed informally to save time.
option_d: Lock alterations and new keys must be done by the Accounting Officer under security conditions.
explanation: FR 1114 centralizes and secures lock-change processes under the Accounting Officer. (FR 1114)

question_text: Which enterprise-wide governance outcome is most aligned with FR 1115?
option_a: Submit returns on 31 December to the Budget Office.
option_b: Submit returns only when new safes are purchased.
option_c: Submit returns quarterly to the Auditor-General only.
option_d: Render annual returns (in duplicate) of all government strong-rooms and safes on 31 March to the Accountant-General for record checks/updates.
explanation: FR 1115 requires annual returns of safes/strong-rooms to the Accountant-General on 31 March. (FR 1115)

question_text: From a system-wide view, what is the core control objective behind FR 1116?
option_a: Hand keys to the transport officer with the safe.
option_b: Notify the Accountant-General immediately of safe transfers between stations/departments and inform duplicate key holders to forward keys securely if needed.
option_c: Notify only after the annual returns are prepared.
option_d: Transfer safes without notification as long as inventory is updated internally.
explanation: FR 1116 ensures AG records and duplicate-key custody stay accurate when safes move. (FR 1116)

question_text: Strategically, FR 1117 is intended to reduce which key risk?
option_a: When locks change or a safe is condemned/destroyed, inform duplicate key holders so old keys are destroyed and removed from records.
option_b: Send old keys to the bank for disposal.
option_c: Keep old keys âjust in caseâ the safe is repaired.
option_d: Retain old keys in the cashierâs desk.
explanation: FR 1117 prevents obsolete keys from remaining in circulation and requires record write-off. (FR 1117)

question_text: Which enterprise-wide governance outcome is most aligned with FR 1118?
option_a: Only authorised key holders may open strong-rooms/safes and they must remain present while open (all key holders present if multiple).
option_b: Allow any senior staff to open the safe if a key holder is absent.
option_c: Permit opening as long as CCTV is installed.
option_d: Open the safe and leave it open while officers attend meetings.
explanation: FR 1118 restricts access to authorised key holders and requires their presence during opening. (FR 1118)

question_text: Which enterprise-wide governance outcome is most aligned with FR 1119?
option_a: Integrity of public funds and prevention of commingling.
option_b: Increasing petty cash flexibility.
option_c: Reducing banking transactions.
option_d: Allowing staff to store valuables safely.
explanation: Prohibiting private money in official safes prevents commingling and protects public fund integrity. (FR 1119)

question_text: Strategically, FR 1120 is intended to reduce which key risk?
option_a: Keep overnight cash in the cashierâs safe for faster morning access.
option_b: Ensure cashierâs cash balance is locked in a strong-room/reserve safe at close daily; where provided, do not keep cash overnight in the cashierâs safe.
option_c: Bank the cash weekly instead of daily locking.
option_d: Leave cash in drawers if the office has security guards.
explanation: FR 1120 sets end-of-day custody: strong-room/reserve safe, not cashierâs safe when a strong-room exists. (FR 1120)

question_text: Which enterprise-wide governance outcome is most aligned with FR 1121?
option_a: Record totals only; denominations are optional.
option_b: Allow entries to be unsigned as long as they are typed.
option_c: Maintain registers only for cash, not stamps or books.
option_d: Keep strong-room/safe registers for cash, stamps, receipt/licence books, etc., showing denominations separately; entries signed by key holders; issue receipts for documents/articles deposited.
explanation: FR 1121 prescribes detailed registers and signature controls for items kept in strong-rooms/safes. (FR 1121)

question_text: From a system-wide view, what is the core control objective behind FR 1122?
option_a: Check contents only during annual stock-taking.
option_b: Sign the register only if discrepancies are found.
option_c: Delegate checks to the cashier without review.
option_d: Sub-Accounting Officers must check strong-room/safe contents at least monthly against the register and sign the register on each occasion; report discrepancies.
explanation: FR 1122 requires monthly reconciliation of physical contents to the register, with signatures and reporting of discrepancies. (FR 1122)

question_text: From a system-wide view, what is the core control objective behind FR 1123?
option_a: Send agreements home with the contract officer.
option_b: Keep bonds only in electronic form without backup.
option_c: Keep bonds/agreements in secure custody; Accounting Officers are responsible if government suffers financially due to poor safeguards.
option_d: Store bonds in open filing cabinets for easy access.
explanation: FR 1123 stresses safe custody of key legal documents and holds AOs accountable for losses due to inadequate precautions. (FR 1123)

question_text: Strategically, FR 1124 is intended to reduce which key risk?
option_a: Leave the key in the key holderâs drawer until return.
option_b: Hand all keys to one officer to simplify access.
option_c: Give the key to any available staff member without record.
option_d: When a key holder is temporarily absent, hand the key to the next officer in rank against signature in the key register; never allow all keys to be held by one officer.
explanation: FR 1124 regulates temporary key handover and forbids concentration of all keys with one officer. (FR 1124)

question_text: Strategically, FR 1125 is intended to reduce which key risk?
option_a: Check contents only if the cash balance seems unusual.
option_b: On any handover of keys, check the contents and insert certificates in the register; report discrepancies to the Accounting Officer.
option_c: File certificates separately; no need to record in the register.
option_d: Handover keys without checking contents to avoid delays.
explanation: FR 1125 requires joint verification and documentation whenever key custody changes. (FR 1125)

question_text: From a system-wide view, what is the core control objective behind FR 1126?
option_a: Release deposited documents/articles only on depositorâs demand and production of the deposit receipt; obtain acknowledgement on the receipt and paste it in the register.
option_b: Release documents if the depositor shows an ID card only.
option_c: Release documents on a verbal request from the depositor.
option_d: Return documents and keep the receipt with the depositor.
explanation: FR 1126 ties release to the deposit receipt and requires acknowledgement and record-keeping. (FR 1126)

question_text: Which enterprise-wide governance outcome is most aligned with FR 1127?
option_a: Keep postage stocks under the sole custody of the cashier.
option_b: Let each unit keep its own postage stocks independently.
option_c: Main stocks of postal valuables (stamps, postal orders, etc.) must be held in joint custody of officers appointed by the Accounting Officer and the Minister of Communications.
option_d: Hold postage stocks with the procurement officer only.
explanation: FR 1127 sets joint-custody arrangements for major postage-related stocks. (FR 1127)

question_text: From a system-wide view, what is the core control objective behind FR 1128?
option_a: Receive valuable letters in open trays for quicker sorting.
option_b: Provide a padlocked Post-Office mail bag for valuable mail; key kept by the officer in charge and opened in his presence.
option_c: Let the cashier keep the padlock key and open the bag alone.
option_d: Allow the postman to open the bag and hand over items.
explanation: FR 1128 secures valuable mail delivery using a padlocked bag and controlled opening. (FR 1128)

question_text: From a system-wide view, what is the core control objective behind FR 1129?
option_a: Maintain a register for inward/outward registered letters (and unregistered valuables), signed by officer-in-charge; file and number Post Office receipts for outward letters and reference them in the register.
option_b: Allow unsigned entries if the register is kept electronically.
option_c: Record only outward letters; inward letters are optional.
option_d: Do not file Post Office receipts once letters are sent.
explanation: FR 1129 requires documented tracking of registered letters and valuables, with signed entries and controlled receipt filing. (FR 1129)

question_text: At top management level, FR 1130 primarily strengthens which principle?
option_a: Lock only contracts; other books can remain in drawers.
option_b: Keep cheque books on the cashierâs desk for convenience.
option_c: Store security documents in open shelves if the room is guarded.
option_d: Lock security documents/forms (e.g., receipt/licence books, cheque books, LPO books, contracts, bonds, insurance policies, securities) overnight in a safe/strong-room/security cabinet and safeguard them during the day.
explanation: FR 1130 lists key security documents and requires robust safe custody arrangements. (FR 1130)

question_text: From a system-wide view, what is the core control objective behind FR 1131?
option_a: Store records near windows for ventilation even overnight.
option_b: Lock only the cash book; other records can remain on tables.
option_c: Protect core accounting records (cash books, ledgers, journals, registers, asset records, used receipt books, etc.) from unauthorised access and fireâpreferably in a strong-room or safe overnight.
option_d: Allow anyone to access ledgers as long as they sign a visitor book.
explanation: FR 1131 mandates precautions (access + fire) for specified accounting records; strong-room/safe is preferred protection. (FR 1131)

question_text: From a system-wide view, what is the core control objective behind FR 1132?
option_a: Retention only for active cases.
option_b: Records governance: retention, auditability, and controlled disposal.
option_c: Informal retention based on convenience.
option_d: Immediate destruction to save space.
explanation: Retention schedules support audit trails and accountability; destruction is controlled and audit-dependent. (FR 1132)

question_text: From a top-management perspective, what is the key risk-control requirement in FR 1201 (responsibility for control)? (Select the option that best reduces enterprise risk.)
option_a: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.
option_b: The responsibility belongs to the cashier alone, not the designated senior officer(s).
option_c: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_d: The Accountant-General controls Treasury Receipt Books (T.B.6) and Revenue Collectorsâ Receipt Books (T.B.6A), while Accounting Officers control Receipt/Licence Books and Fixed Fee Tickets and ensure safe custody.
explanation: FR 1201 requires: The Accountant-General controls Treasury Receipt Books (T.B.6) and Revenue Collectorsâ Receipt Books (T.B.6A), while Accounting Officers control Receipt/Licence Books and Fixed Fee Tickets and ensure safe custody.

question_text: Which enterprise-level policy best enforces FR 1202 (printing/numbering requirements) across MDAs? (Select the option that best reduces enterprise risk.)
option_a: The document may be handled by any printer/bank/office without special approval.

option_b: The action is optional and may be done at the officerâs discretion.
option_c: The requirement applies only at year-end and not during routine operations.
option_d: Deposit ledgers must be balanced and ruled off at financial year end, carrying down outstanding balances with adequate cross-references.
explanation: FR 1313 requires: Deposit ledgers must be balanced and ruled off at financial year end, carrying down outstanding balances with adequate cross-references.

question_text: Which enterprise-wide control stance best matches the intent of FR 1401?
option_a: An imprest issued for routine office expenditure, repayable only at year-end.
option_b: Any advance to an officer, whether personal or official, authorised solely by the Accountant-General.
option_c: A deposit held below-the-line for third parties and refundable on demand.
option_d: Ensure that: A cash loan to an individual federal officer, grantable only under the Financial Regulations and Public Service Rules.
explanation: FR 1401 limits personal advances to cash loans to individual officers and restricts them to the authority of the Financial Regulations and Public Service Rules.

question_text: From a system-wide risk perspective, what is the best top-management decision under FR 1402?
option_a: Any advance above ?50,000 that can be approved by the Accounting Officer without exception.
option_b: A cash loan to an officer for private needs, approved by any Head of Department without limits.
option_c: Ensure that: An official-capacity advance (e.g., imprest/loss-of-funds), generally requiring Minister of Finance approval except FR 2524 cases or up to ?50,000 approved by the Accounting Officer, with applications stating reason, clearance method, and responsible person.
option_d: A revenue refund mechanism that must always be approved by the Auditor-General.
explanation: FR 1402 defines non-personal advances and sets approval rules (Minister of Finance, with stated exceptions), plus application content and project governance.

question_text: From a system-wide risk perspective, what is the best top-management decision under FR 1403?
option_a: Only the suppliers invoice reference and LPO number.
option_b: Only the cheque number and bank account designation.
option_c: Ensure that: Officers name/designation, below-the-line classification code, nature of advance, recovery terms, and authority for the advance.
option_d: Only the vote book sub-head and the paying station code.
explanation: FR 1403 specifies the mandatory particulars that must appear on vouchers relating to advances.

question_text: Which strategic directive best enforces FR 1404 across government operations?
option_a: Record advances only at year-end and reconcile only during external audit.
option_b: Keep advance records unindexed and reconcile only when a query is raised.
option_c: Maintain fully indexed advance account records, post transactions promptly, reconcile monthly with the Accountant-Generals control, and flag overdue items to the Accounting Officer.
option_d: Delegate advance ledger control entirely to the cashier without review.
explanation: FR 1404 sets record-keeping, timeliness, reconciliation, and monitoring requirements for advance accounts.

question_text: From a system-wide risk perspective, what is the best top-management decision under FR 1405?
option_a: Ensure advances are written off automatically after one year.
option_b: Ensure advances are charged to revenue heads until recovered.
option_c: Ensure advances are converted to deposits when repayment delays occur.
option_d: Ensure advances are repaid promptly, whether by instalments or otherwise.
explanation: FR 1405 assigns Accounting Officers responsibility for prompt repayment of all advances.

question_text: Which enterprise-wide control stance best matches the intent of FR 1406?
option_a: Grant up to three months salary advance automatically to any transferring officer.
option_b: Grant an imprest instead of a salary advance for family transport costs.
option_c: Grant advance only after the officer returns and submits vouchers.
option_d: Ensure that: Grant up to one months salary advance to an officer on transfer who bears transport costs wholly or partly.
explanation: FR 1406 allows a salary advance on transfer, capped at one months salary, tied to transport costs borne by the officer.

question_text: Which strategic directive best enforces FR 1407 across government operations?
option_a: Ensure that: Approve a salary advance up to one months salary for an officer posted to an overseas office/duty.
option_b: Approve payment only through deposits, not salary advances.
option_c: Approve an estacode advance up to three months salary for any overseas posting.
option_d: Approve an advance only if the officer is GL.15 and above.
explanation: FR 1407 provides for a salary advance of up to one months salary for overseas posting.

question_text: At top management level, which governance position is most consistent with FR 1408?
option_a: Ensure that: On first appointment, grant up to one months salary; for temporary appointment, grant up to one months salary only with an acceptable guarantee.
option_b: Grant temporary appointees salary advances without any guarantee requirement.
option_c: Grant advances only after confirmation of appointment.
option_d: Grant two months salary to all first appointees as entitlement.
explanation: FR 1408 sets limits for first appointment and adds a guarantee condition for temporary appointments.

question_text: From a system-wide risk perspective, what is the best top-management decision under FR 1409?
option_a: Repay 1-month advance over 6 instalments and allow deductions up to 75% of salary.
option_b: Repay all salary advances in a single lump sum within 30 days, regardless of amount.
option_c: Ensure that: Repay 1-month advance in 3 equal consecutive instalments starting next month; 2- and 3-month advances in up to 6 and 9 instalments; total deductions must not exceed half monthly salary.
option_d: Repay 3-month advance over 12 instalments and start deductions immediately in the same month.
explanation: FR 1409 fixes instalment lengths by advance size and caps total deductions at not more than half of monthly salary.

question_text: Which enterprise-wide control stance best matches the intent of FR 1410?
option_a: Ensure that: Classify salary advances and recoveries to the below-the-line advance account in the officers name, not to personal emoluments.
option_b: Classify advances to capital sub-heads and recoveries to suspense accounts.
option_c: Classify recoveries to revenue heads and advances to overhead cost vote.
option_d: Classify salary advances to personal emoluments vote to simplify reconciliation.
explanation: FR 1410 is a classification rule: below-the-line advance account in the officers name; never personal emoluments vote.

question_text: From a system-wide risk perspective, what is the best top-management decision under FR 1411?
option_a: Per diem rates are set by each ministry quarterly and must be retired to deposit accounts.
option_b: Uniform ?10,000 per diem for all grades, with retirement required within 48 hours.
option_c: Ensure that: Local DTA per diem rates by cadre (?35,000; ?20,000; ?16,000; ?12,000; ?5,000) with ?20/km transport where no air, plus 30% local running; only for approved tours; charge direct to vote without retirement.
option_d: Per diem excludes feeding and is payable only after audit clearance; transport is per-mile at a fixed dollar rate.
explanation: FR 1411 sets specific per diem and transport rules for duty tours within Nigeria, plus charging and approval conditions.

question_text: From a system-wide risk perspective, what is the best top-management decision under FR 1412?
option_a: Estacode is authorised by the Auditor-General and paid as a fixed monthly allowance.
option_b: Ensure that: Accounting Officer authorises estacode at prevailing rates: $900, $600, $425, $381, $206 per diem by cadre.
option_c: Estacode rates are uniform at $300 per diem regardless of grade.
option_d: Estacode is paid only after return from travel and must be retired like an imprest.
explanation: FR 1412 specifies that the Accounting Officer authorises estacode and provides the grade-based per diem rates.

question_text: Which enterprise-wide control stance best matches the intent of FR 1413?
option_a: Pay estacode in cash abroad from mission revenue accounts without approvals.
option_b: Issue estacode as bank drafts payable to the mission and later reallocate by journal entry.
option_c: Pay additional estacode automatically if the officer overstays, without refund obligation.
option_d: Ensure that: Draw estacode in Nigeria as travellers cheques payable to the officer(s) from CBN; extra estacode by mission requires Accounting Officer approval and must be refunded by the ministry/agency.
explanation: FR 1413 prescribes the instrument (travellers cheques), source (CBN), and approval/refund rules for additional estacode.

question_text: Which strategic directive best enforces FR 1414 across government operations?
option_a: Overstay is allowed if the officer uses personal funds for extra days.
option_b: Overstay is allowed if the officer sends an email to the paying officer after the fact.
option_c: Overstay is allowed for GL.15 and above without further approvals.
option_d: Ensure that: Do not overstay the approved number of days on duty tour without prior Accounting Officer approval.
explanation: FR 1414 is a strict approval rule: no overstaying locally or overseas without prior Accounting Officer approval.

question_text: From a system-wide risk perspective, what is the best top-management decision under FR 1415?
option_a: Charge interest on the advance and recover over any period the officer requests.
option_b: Allow advances for any course, including unrelated hobbies, and include exam/other fees.
option_c: Ensure that: Authorise only if conditions are met: work-related, efficiency benefit, reputable institution, receipts produced, TF51 repayment agreement (+ surety if <2 years service), interest-free, excludes postage/stationery/exam fees, recover within 24 instalments.
option_d: Approve without agreement forms provided the officer promises to repay verbally.
explanation: FR 1415 lists strict eligibility, documentation (TF51/surety), cost exclusions, and recovery limits for study-related advances.

question_text: At top management level, which governance position is most consistent with FR 1416?
option_a: Transfer the balance to revenue once the officer leaves.
option_b: Write off the balance when an officer resigns if more than half has been recovered.
option_c: Suspend recovery until the next financial year to avoid excess expenditure.
option_d: Ensure that: Recover the outstanding balance in full from the officers last salary and/or retirement gratuity on exit.
explanation: FR 1416 mandates full recovery of any outstanding advance balance from final salary and/or gratuity upon leaving service.

question_text: From a system-wide risk perspective, what is the best top-management decision under FR 1417?
option_a: Ensure that: Do not recover the outstanding salary advance balance from the estate where the deceased officer is not entitled to gratuity; government bears the irrecoverable balance.
option_b: Recover from the estate in all cases, regardless of gratuity entitlement.
option_c: Recover from next of kins salary if employed in government.
option_d: Convert the balance to a deposit and hold for five years before transfer to revenue.
explanation: FR 1417 creates a specific exception: if no gratuity entitlement, the estate is not charged; government accepts liability.

question_text: Which strategic directive best enforces FR 1418 across government operations?
option_a: Convert the outstanding balance to an imprest at the new station.
option_b: Close the advance ledger at the old station and restart recovery from zero at the new station.
option_c: State advance details and recoveries in the Last Pay Certificate sent to the new station with certified true Personal Emolument Record; new station SAO records the balance and continues recovery.
option_d: Send only a verbal handover note; the Personal Emolument Record is not required.
explanation: FR 1418 establishes the documentation and continuity steps for recovering advances after transfer to a new pay station.

question_text: Which strategic directive best enforces FR 1419 across government operations?
option_a: If advice is missing, recoveries must wait until the officer requests deduction.
option_b: If advice is missing, instalments are waived automatically.
option_c: If advice is missing, convert the instalments to interest-bearing debt.
option_d: The absence of advice does not excuse non-repayment; missed instalments are deducted en bloc once the appropriate documents arrive.
explanation: FR 1419 makes repayment obligatory regardless of advice and permits en bloc deduction of missed instalments once documentation is received.

question_text: From a system-wide risk perspective, what is the best top-management decision under FR 1420?
option_a: Ensure advances are classified to overhead votes to simplify budgeting.
option_b: Ensure advances are issued promptly even if recovery systems are not in place.
option_c: Ensure advances are retired only at the end of the officers career.
option_d: Ensure that all advances granted are fully recovered.
explanation: FR 1420 states the Accounting Officers overarching duty: complete recovery of all advances.

option_b: Compliance must follow the specific provision stated in FR 1501
option_c: It applies only when funds permit
option_d: It is discretionary for departments
explanation: FR 1501 explicitly requires adherence to its stated rule.

question_text: At executive policy level, the defining test of selfâaccounting designation is whether the unit can:
option_a: Operate independently of audit
option_b: Account to AGF in prescribed form
option_c: Set its own budget
option_d: Ignore treasury rules
explanation: Ultimate criterion is accountability to AccountantâGeneral.

question_text: Strategically, AG approval conditions ensure:
option_a: Political neutrality
option_b: Operational accounting capacity
option_c: Media compliance
option_d: Regional balance
explanation: They ensure capability to manage accounts properly.

question_text: At executive governance level this rule safeguards:
option_a: Political influence
option_b: Integrity of financial records
option_c: Union relations
option_d: Procurement speed
explanation: It protects record integrity.

question_text: Strategic intent of these duties is to ensure:
option_a: Administrative convenience
option_b: Financial accuracy assurance
option_c: Staff rotation
option_d: Office expansion
explanation: They ensure accuracy of payments.

question_text: Executive oversight objective is ensuring:
option_a: Political compliance
option_b: Reliable budget performance reporting
option_c: Staff morale
option_d: Media coverage
explanation: Reports inform management.

question_text: Governance rationale is to preserve:
option_a: Office culture
option_b: Audit evidence
option_c: Furniture
option_d: Lighting
explanation: Records provide evidence.

question_text: Strategic purpose is:
option_a: Reduce printing
option_b: Prevent misstatement
option_c: Increase staff
option_d: Improve lighting
explanation: Reconciliation prevents errors.

question_text: Executive control principle here is:
option_a: Centralisation
option_b: Immediate escalation of anomalies
option_c: Delegation
option_d: Rotation
explanation: Immediate reporting protects funds.

question_text: Strategic intent is to guarantee:
option_a: Flexibility

option_c: Autonomy

question_text: Executive governance logic for this power is to:
option_a: Reward units
option_b: Enforce accountability

question_text: At executive level, which policy directive best institutionalises FR 1701 compliance on Internal Audit meaning and responsibility?
option_a: Internal Audit is a managerial control that measures/evaluates effectiveness of Internal Control system
option_b: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_c: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_d: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
explanation: FR 1701 emphasises that Internal Audit is a managerial control that measures/evaluates effectiveness of Internal Control system.

question_text: Which strategic governance stance most directly enforces FR 1702 across agencies for Placement of competent accountant for IA units?
option_a: Accountant-General ensures suitably competent Accountant placed directly in charge of Internal Audit Units
option_b: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_c: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_d: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
explanation: FR 1702 emphasises that Accountant-General ensures suitably competent Accountant placed directly in charge of Internal Audit Units.

question_text: Which top-management instruction best drives organisation-wide compliance with FR 1703 on Reporting lines and programme of audit?
option_a: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_b: Issues special reports on irregularity, procedure weakness, inattention to Auditor-General reports, or earlier IA reports
option_c: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_d: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
explanation: FR 1703 emphasises that Issues special reports on irregularity, procedure weakness, inattention to Auditor-General reports, or earlier IA reports.

question_text: Which high-level control principle most aligns with FR 1704 expectations for Annual audit programme scope?
option_a: Programme covers safeguards against fraud/loss, revenue control, expenditure control, stores control, verification of cash/stores/assets, accuracy of records
option_b: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_c: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_d: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
explanation: FR 1704 emphasises that Programme covers safeguards against fraud/loss, revenue control, expenditure control, stores control, verification of cash/stores/assets, accuracy of records.

question_text: At executive level, which policy directive best institutionalises FR 1705 compliance on Pre-payment audit and 48-hour rule?
option_a: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_b: Only sample-based (10%) pre-payment audit is required for checked vouchers.
option_c: Vouchers forwarded under security schedule direct to appropriate CPO for payment
option_d: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
explanation: FR 1705 emphasises that Vouchers forwarded under security schedule direct to appropriate CPO for payment.

question_text: Which strategic governance stance most directly enforces FR 1706 across agencies for Periodic IA reports and content?
option_a: Issues special reports on irregularity/weakness and draws attention to Auditor-General or earlier IA reports; copies forwarded to AG and Auditor-General
option_b: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_c: Internal Audit reports are submitted only annually, not monthly/quarterly/half-yearly.
option_d: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
explanation: FR 1706 emphasises that Issues special reports on irregularity/weakness and draws attention to Auditor-General or earlier IA reports; copies forwarded to AG and Auditor-General.

question_text: Which top-management instruction best drives organisation-wide compliance with FR 1707 on Register to track audit progress?
option_a: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_b: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_c: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_d: Head IA maintains under personal control a register to record progress of the audit
explanation: FR 1707 emphasises that Head IA maintains under personal control a register to record progress of the audit.

question_text: Which high-level control principle most aligns with FR 1708 expectations for Internal audit instructions?
option_a: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_b: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_c: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_d: Head IA draws up detailed IA instructions for staff; comprehensive amplification of audit guide
explanation: FR 1708 emphasises that Head IA draws up detailed IA instructions for staff; comprehensive amplification of audit guide.

question_text: At executive level, which policy directive best institutionalises FR 1709 compliance on Independence of IA staff?
option_a: Officer previously engaged on accounting duties in the same ministry/unit is precluded from taking up IA duties
option_b: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_c: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_d: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
explanation: FR 1709 emphasises that Officer previously engaged on accounting duties in the same ministry/unit is precluded from taking up IA duties.

question_text: Which strategic governance stance most directly enforces FR 1710 across agencies for Internal audit stamps as security instruments?
option_a: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_b: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_c: IA certification is through Internal Audit stamps
option_d: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
explanation: FR 1710 emphasises that IA certification is through Internal Audit stamps.

question_text: Which top-management instruction best drives organisation-wide compliance with FR 1711 on Eligibility and application for audit stamps?
option_a: Particulars: name/rank, two passport photos stamped/endorsed, specimen signatures, evidence of posting
option_b: Passport photographs are optional if specimen signatures are provided.
option_c: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_d: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
explanation: FR 1711 emphasises that Particulars: name/rank, two passport photos stamped/endorsed, specimen signatures, evidence of posting.

question_text: Which high-level control principle most aligns with FR 1712 expectations for Daily custody and register for audit stamps?
option_a: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
option_b: Head IA collects all audit stamps end of each day; locks in Treasury Safe with two senior officers holding keys (one being Head IA)
option_c: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_d: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
explanation: FR 1712 emphasises that Head IA collects all audit stamps end of each day; locks in Treasury Safe with two senior officers holding keys (one being Head IA).

question_text: At executive level, which policy directive best institutionalises FR 1713 compliance on Non-transferability and return of stamps?
option_a: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_b: Audit stamps can be transferred to a colleague on the same grade level.
option_c: Audit stamps are not transferable
option_d: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
explanation: FR 1713 emphasises that Audit stamps are not transferable.

question_text: Which strategic governance stance most directly enforces FR 1714 across agencies for Sanctions for loss of audit stamp?
option_a: Vouchers may be held in Internal Audit until month-end to reduce paperwork.
option_b: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_c: Audit stamps may be shared among auditors to speed up certification.
option_d: Internal auditor who loses an audit stamp through negligence bears maximum penalty of surcharge or replacement cost as confirmed by Accountant-General
explanation: FR 1714 emphasises that Internal auditor who loses an audit stamp through negligence bears maximum penalty of surcharge or replacement cost as confirmed by Accountant-General.

question_text: Which top-management instruction best drives organisation-wide compliance with FR 1715 on Access rights of Internal Auditor?
option_a: Internal Auditors may be assigned routine accounting duties to cover staff shortages.
option_b: Internal Auditor has free access at reasonable times to stores and store records for independent audit
option_c: Internal Audit replaces normal departmental checks once the unit exists.
option_d: Internal Audit certification must be by handwritten endorsement only.
explanation: FR 1715 emphasises that Internal Auditor has free access at reasonable times to stores and store records for independent audit.

question_text: Which high-level control principle most aligns with FR 1801 expectations for Annual boards of survey (domestic)?
option_a: Reports of Boards of Survey may be submitted within six weeks after the survey.
option_b: A Board of Survey may be constituted with members below GL.08 if supervised.
option_c: Cash transactions may continue during a survey provided they are recorded in the cash book.
option_d: Examine cash, bank balances, and stamps held at sub-treasury, FPOs, cash offices in ministries etc
explanation: FR 1801 emphasises that Examine cash, bank balances, and stamps held at sub-treasury, FPOs, cash offices in ministries etc.

question_text: At executive level, which policy directive best institutionalises FR 1802 compliance on Annual boards of survey (missions overseas)?
option_a: Boards of Survey are held only at the end of each quarter, not at year-end.
option_b: Annual boards for missions overseas on cash/bank/stamps held; Head of Mission convenes
option_c: A Board of Survey may be constituted with members below GL.08 if supervised.
option_d: Cash transactions may continue during a survey provided they are recorded in the cash book.
explanation: FR 1802 emphasises that Annual boards for missions overseas on cash/bank/stamps held; Head of Mission convenes.

question_text: Which strategic governance stance most directly enforces FR 1803 across agencies for Surprise boards of survey (domestic)?
option_a: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
option_b: A Board of Survey may be constituted with members below GL.08 if supervised.
option_c: Boards of Survey are held only at the end of each quarter, not at year-end.
option_d: Once in each of first three quarters; not necessarily end of month/quarter
explanation: FR 1803 emphasises that Once in each of first three quarters; not necessarily end of month/quarter.

question_text: Which top-management instruction best drives organisation-wide compliance with FR 1804 on Surprise boards of survey (missions overseas)?
option_a: A Board of Survey may be constituted with members below GL.08 if supervised.
option_b: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
option_c: Surprise boards at missions overseas three times each year; Head of Mission convenes; held at intervals as 1803
option_d: Cash transactions may continue during a survey provided they are recorded in the cash book.
explanation: FR 1804 emphasises that Surprise boards at missions overseas three times each year; Head of Mission convenes; held at intervals as 1803.

question_text: Which high-level control principle most aligns with FR 1805 expectations for Composition and conduct of board?
option_a: Surpluses discovered during survey are treated as staff welfare after approval.
option_b: Members unable to serve must report immediately to convening authority
option_c: Reports of Boards of Survey may be submitted within six weeks after the survey.
option_d: Cash transactions may continue during a survey provided they are recorded in the cash book.
explanation: FR 1805 emphasises that Members unable to serve must report immediately to convening authority.

question_text: At executive level, which policy directive best institutionalises FR 1806 compliance on Suspension of cash transactions during survey?
option_a: Unverified cash may be kept in the cashierâs drawer if the safe is full.
option_b: A Board of Survey may be constituted with members below GL.08 if supervised.
option_c: If survey not completed in one day, unverified cash kept separately in safe
option_d: Cash transactions may occur between year-end close and survey if countersigned by the Board.
explanation: FR 1806 emphasises that If survey not completed in one day, unverified cash kept separately in safe.

question_text: Which strategic governance stance most directly enforces FR 1807 across agencies for Certification and treatment of surplus/shortage?
option_a: Reports of Boards of Survey may be submitted within six weeks after the survey.
option_b: Cash transactions may continue during a survey provided they are recorded in the cash book.
option_c: A Board of Survey may be constituted with members below GL.08 if supervised.
option_d: Surplus credited to revenue head: Miscellaneous, Sub-head: Sundries; shortage made good or charged to advance for investigation; serious shortage reported immediately to AG with copy to Auditor-General per Chapter 25
explanation: FR 1807 emphasises that Surplus credited to revenue head: Miscellaneous, Sub-head: Sundries; shortage made good or charged to advance for investigation; serious shortage reported immediately to AG with copy to Auditor-General per Chapter 25.

question_text: Which top-management instruction best drives organisation-wide compliance with FR 1808 on Board report TF42 and timelines?
option_a: President forwards not later than two weeks after survey to AG who transmits copies to Auditor-General and Accounting Officer
option_b: Cash transactions may continue during a survey provided they are recorded in the cash book.
option_c: Boards of Survey are held only at the end of each quarter, not at year-end.
option_d: A Board of Survey may be constituted with members below GL.08 if supervised.
explanation: FR 1808 emphasises that President forwards not later than two weeks after survey to AG who transmits copies to Auditor-General and Accounting Officer.

question_text: Which high-level control principle most aligns with FR 1809 expectations for Irregular inspections by Accounting Officers?
option_a: Cash transactions may continue during a survey provided they are recorded in the cash book.
option_b: Reports of Boards of Survey may be submitted within six weeks after the survey.
option_c: Inspection records are optional if no discrepancies are found.
option_d: Accounting Officers issue instructions for systematic inspection at irregular intervals of cash held by subordinate officers; record kept
explanation: FR 1809 emphasises that Accounting Officers issue instructions for systematic inspection at irregular intervals of cash held by subordinate officers; record kept.
